children.definition: αʹ = εἷς and πρῶτος, but ͵α = 1,000.

definition: ἀ-, as insep. Prefix in compos.:

children.label: I
children.definition: α στερητικόν (Sch. Od. 3.279, etc., cf. Eust. 985.16), expressing want or absence (cf. Arist. Metaph. 1022b32), as σοφός wise, ἄσοφος unwise: for ṇ, the weak form of the negative ne, commonly used in the formation of adjs. and advbs., very rarely in that of vbs. and substs., cf. ἀδώτης, ἀτιμάω, ἀτίω. Before a vowel it usu. appears as ἀν- (exc. where ϝ or spiritus asper has been lost, as ἄ-οινος, ἄ-υπνος, when it sts. coalesces with the following vowel, as ἀργός = ἀ-ϝεργός): the forms ἀνάεδνος, ἀνάελπτος are probably misspelt for ἀν-έϝεδνος, -έϝελπτος. Adjs. formed with it freq. take gen., esp. in Trag., cf. ἀλαμπὲς ἡλίου, = ἄνευ λάμψεως ἡλίου, S. Tr. 691. [ ᾰ, exc. in adjs. which begin with three short syllables, which have ᾱ in Ep., and freq. also in Lyr., Trag., and Com.; ἀθάνατος invariably has ᾱθ.]

children.label: II
children.definition: α ἀθροιστικόν ( Eust. 641.61; τὸ ἄλφα σημαίνει πολλαχοῦ τὸ ὁμοῦ Pl. Cra. 405c), properly ἁ- since it represents sṃ- (cf. ἅμα, εἷς = sems), and so in ἁπλόος, ἁθρόος: but freq. ἀ- by dissimilation from following aspirate, as ἄ-λοχος, and hence by analogy in ἄ-κοιτις, etc., q.v.: sts. in the form ὀ-, as in ὄπατρος, ὀγάστριος, ὄζυξ. [ᾰ.]

data.quote: τὸ ἄλφα σημαίνει πολλαχοῦ τὸ ὁμοῦ

children.label: III
children.definition: α ἐπιτατικόν ( Eust. 641.61), strengthening the force of compds., as ἀ-τενής; prob. identical in etymology with II, from which it is distinguished by Gramm., who sts. confuse it with I; v. ἀδάκρυτος. [ᾰ.]

data.ref: Eust. 641.61), strengthening the force of compds., as

definition: ἀ- as a prothetic vowel, usually before a double consonant, as ἀ-βληχρός, ἀ-σπαίρω; sts. before a single consonant, as ἀ-μέλγω; before a vowel where ϝ is lost, as ἀ-ϝείδω. [ᾰ.]

children.definition: Hom. always ἆ δειλέ, ἆ δειλώ, ἆ δειλοί, Il. 11.441, 17.443, Od. 20.351, cf. Thgn. 351, Theoc. Ep. 6; also in Lyr., Archil. 135, and Trag., A. Ag. 1087, etc.; in reproofs or warnings, ἆ, μηδαμῶς . . S. Ph. 1300, cf. OT 1147, E. Hel. 445, etc.:—freq. with adj., ἆ μάκαρ Thgn. 1013, Choeril. 1; ἆ τάλας Semon. 7.76, cf. B. 15.30; ἆ τρισευδαίμων Id. 3.10; rarely alone, Ar. Ra. 759; sts. doubled, ἆ ἆ A. Pr. 114, 566, Ar. V. 1379. —Rare in Prose, Pl. Hp.Ma. 295a (Euclus ap. Sch. ad loc. is said to have used it = νῦν).

data.ref: A. Ag. 1087, etc.; in reproofs or warnings,
Pl. Hp.Ma. 295a (Euclus ap. Sch. ad loc. is said to have used it = νῦν).

definition: ἃ ἅ or ἇ ἇ, to express laughter,

children.definition: ha ha, E. Cyc. 157, Pl.Com. 16 (prob. l.), etc.; ἃ ἃ δασυνθὲν γέλωτα δηλοῖ Hsch., Phot., Eust. 855.19.

definition: ἄα σύστημα ὕδατος, Hsch., Phot., cf. Et.Gud.

definition: ἄαδα ἔνδεια ( Lacon.), Hsch. ἀαδεῖν· ὀχλεῖν, ἀπορεῖν, Et.Gud., cf. Hsch., Phot. p.3R. (prob. for ἀ-ϝαδεῖν, cf. ἀαδής).
ἀαδένη ( ἀαδέν Et.Gud., Cyr.) · ὑεία κόπρος, Hsch.

breathe with the mouth wide open, Arist. Pr. 964a11. (Onomatopoeic word, for ἀἅζω, make the sound aha!)
barbless, Cyr. ἄακτος, ον, = ἀαγής, Hsch., Et.Gud.

ἀανές ( ἄνω) · οὐ τελεσθησόμενον, Hsch.:—also ἀάνης· χρήσιμος, Id., Et.Gud.

children.definition: ear-ring, Alcm. 120, Ar. Fr. 926.

definition: ἀάπλετος, ον, lengthd. Ep. for ἄπλετος, v.l. in Q.S. 1.675.

children.definition: not to be touched, resistless, invincible, χεῖρες Hom. (mostly in Il., as 1.567), Hes. Op. 148; κῆτος ἄ. Opp. H. 5.629. ( Ar.Byz. read ἄεπτος (q. v.) in Hom.; cf. ἀπτοεπής.)
to-morrow or the day after to-morrow, gen. of ἄα, = ἠώς, read by Zenod. for ἠοῦς in Il. 8.470 (cf. Sch.Ven.); as Adv. in Boeot., Hsch.; cf. ἀές.

definition: ἀασιφόρος βλάβην φέρων, Hsch., Et.Gud., cf. EM 1.49.

breathing out, expiration, Arist. Pr. 964a18.

definition: ἀάσπετος, ἀάσχετος, v. sub ἄσπετος, ἄσχετος.

insatiate, c. gen., ἄατος πολέμοιο Hes. Th. 714; Ἄρης ἆτος πολέμοιο Il. 5.388; μάχης ἆτόν περ ἐόντα 22.218: abs., ἄατος ὕβρις A.R. 1.459. [First syll. short in Hes., long in A.R.]

definition: ἀάω, Ep. Verb (twice in Trag., v. infr.), used by Hom. in aor. Act. ἄᾰσα ( ᾱᾱσαν Od. 10.68, later ᾰᾱσε prob. in Matro Conv. 29) contr. ἆσα, Med. ἀᾰσάμην ( ἀᾱσατο, v.l. ἀάσσατο, Il. 9.537) contr. ἀσάμην, Pass. ἀάσθην: pres. only in 3 sg. Med. ἀᾶται Il. 19.91:—

children.definition: hurt, damage, always in reference to the mind, mislead, infatuate, of the effects of wine, sleep, divine judgements, etc., ἄασάν μʼ ἕταροί τε κακοὶ πρὸς τοῖσί τε ὕπνος Od. 10.68; ἆσέ με δαίμονος αἶσα κακὴ καὶ . . οἶνος 11.61; φρένας ἄασε οἴνῳ 21.297; of love, θαλερὴ δέ μιν ἄασε Κύπρις Epic. ap. Parth. 21.2; inf. ἆσαι A. Fr. 417; part. ἄσας S. Fr. 628:— Med., Ἄτη ἣ πάντας ἀᾶται Il. 19.91 :— Pass., Ἄτης, ᾗ πρῶτον ἀάσθην Il. 19.136, cf. Hes. Op. 283, h.Cer. 258.

data.quote: ἄασάν μʼ ἕταροί τε κακοὶ πρὸς τοῖσί τε ὕπνος
ἆσέ με δαίμονος αἶσα κακὴ καὶ . . οἶνος

children.definition: aor. Med., to be infatuated, act foolishly, ἀασάμην Il. 9.116, etc.; ἀάσατο δὲ μέγα θυμῷ ib. 537, 11.340; καὶ γὰρ δή νύ ποτε Ζεὺς ἄσατο 19.95, Aristarch., v.l. Ζῆνʼ ἄσατο (sc. Ἄτη), cf. Sch.Ven. ad loc.; εἴ τί περ ἀασάμην A.R. 1.1333; ἀασάμην . . ἄτην 2.623. ( ἀϝάω, cf. ἀτάω.)

not deep, φάλαγξ Arr. Tact. 5.6; in single rank, ἡ ἐφʼ ἑνὸς ἀ. τάξις ib. 17.5, ἕλκεα Aret. SA 1.9, Gal. 11.127.
without depth, ἐπιφάνεια S.E. P. 3.43, cf. Simp. in Ph. 572.25.
without foundation, Cyr.

slabs (?) in theatre, Suid. s.v. ἄβαξι.

like an ἄβαξ, Sch. Theoc. 4.61.

definition: ἀβάλε [ᾱβᾰ], properly ἆ βάλε, expressing a wish,

not seasoned, of food, Pyrgion ap. Ath. 4.143e.
slab, board:
reckoning-board, used for counting votes, Arist. Ath. 69.1.

dice-board, Caryst. 3.
sideboard, Ammon. Diff. 1.
trencher, plate, Cratin. 86, cf. BCH 29.510 ( Delos, iii B.C.).

marble wall-slab, Id. 7.3.10.

children.label: II

without weight, Arist. Cael. 277b19; ἀβαρῆ εἶναι ἀέρα καὶ πῦρ Zeno Stoic. 1.27, cf. Chrysipp.Stoic. 2.143, Plot. 6.9.9, etc.; light, γῆ AP 7.461 ( Mel.): metaph., ἀ. χρῆμα a light matter, Com.Adesp. 158; παρρησία . . μαλακὴ καὶ ἀ. Plu. Adul. 2.59c; of the pulse, Archig. ap. Gal. 8.651.

children.label: II
children.definition: not offensive, ὀσμαί Aret. CA 2.3; of persons, not burdensome, ἀ. ἑαυτὸν τηρεῖν, παρέχειν, 2 Ep.Cor. 11.9, CIG 5361.15 ( Berenice). Adv. -ρῶς without giving offence, Simp. in Epict. p.85D.; without taking offence, ib. p.88D.

having no boat, landsman, Hsch. ἀβαριστάν· γυναικιζομένην ( Cypr.), Id. ἀβαρκνᾷ· κομᾶ (Maced.), but ἄβαρκνα· λιμός, Id. ἀβαρλεῖται· ταράσσεται, κροτεῖ, Id. ἀβάρνου· στένε, Id. ἀβαρταί, = πτηναί ( Cypr.), Id. ἀβαρύ, = ὀρίγανον (Maced.), Id. ἀβάς· εὐήθης; also = ἱερὰ νόσος ( Tarent.), Id. ἀβάσαι· ἀριστῆσαι, καὶ ἀρθῆναι, Id.
not tortured, ἀ. θνῄσκειν J. BJ 1.32.3, cf. Plu. Aet.Gr. 2.275c; κημοῖς ὑπερῴαν ἀ. Ael. NA 13.9. Adv. -τως without pain, βλέπειν τὸν ἥλιον ib. 10.14.
untried, unexamined, ἀ. τι ἐᾶσαι Antipho 1.13; ἀπολιπεῖν Plb. 4.75.3; παραλείπειν Plu. Adul. 2.59c. Adv. -τως without due examination, Th. 1.20, Plu. Aud.poet. 2.28b.
not ruled by a king, Th. 2.80, X. HG 5.2.17: generally, free from rule, Plu. Col. 2.1125d, Artem. 1.8.
free from malice, perh. to be read for ἀβασάν-, Plu. Amat. 2.755d.
free from envy, Teles p. 56.1 H.; τὸ ἀ. Ph. 1.252; unprejudiced, μάρτυς J. BJ 1.9.4. Adv. -νως M.Ant. 1.16.

secure against enchantments, free from harm, CIG 5053,5119 ( Nubia), Cat.Cod.Astr. 7.234; esp. of children, BGU 8.11, al., POxy. 300 (i A. D.):— in act. sense, acting as a charm or protection against witchcraft, ἀ. ἀνθρώποις καὶ ζῴοις v.l. in Dsc. 3.91. Adv. -τως, ὑγιαίνειν POxy. 292 (i A. D.), cf. AP 11.267.

An. 5.6.9; ἅλς Pi. l.c.; ὕλη Str. 5.4.5; εἶναι εἰς ἄβατον to be made desolate, LXX Je. 29.17, al.: metaph., inaccessible, τὸ πόρσω σοφοῖς ἄ. κἀσόφοις Pi. O. 3.44; οἰκίαι ἄ. τοῖς ἔχουσι μηδὲ ἕν Aristopho 3; ἀ. ποιεῖν τὰς τραπέζας Anaxipp. 3; [τὸ ἀγαθὸν] ἐν ἀβάτοις ὑπεριδρυμένον Procl. in Alc. p.319C.

not ridden, Luc. Zeux. 6; of female animals, Id. Lex. 19.

definition: ἄβδης, ὁ, said by Hsch. to mean

Plb. 15.34.2; αἰτία Epicur. Ep. 3, p.65U.; φιλία Arist. EE 1236b19; τὸ ἀ. = ἀβεβαιότης, Hierocl. in CA 2p.422M., Heraclit. Ep. 7; ἐξ ἀβεβαίου from an insecure position, Arr. An. 1.15.2.

children.label: I
children.definition: Pass., unharmed, unhurt, Sapph. 5.1 LP, Pi. O. 13.27, P. 8.54, A. Th. 68, X. Cyr. 4.1.3, Pl. R. 342b, etc.; ζῶσαν ἀβλαβεῖ βίῳ S. El. 650. Adv. ἀβλαβῶς, Ion. -έως, safely, ζώειν Thgn. 1154; ἔχειν Dexipp. p.148D., cf. Arr. An. 6.19.2: Sup. -έστατα X. Eq. 6.1:— securely, ἐδήσατο σάνδαλα h.Merc. 83.

children.label: II
children.definition: Act., not harming, harmless, innocent, ξυνουσία A. Eu. 285; ἡδοναί Pl. R. 357b, etc.; ἀ. σπασμοί doing no serious injury, Hp. Epid. 1.[2.]6; τὸ πρὸς ἀνθρώπους ἀ. Phld. Piet. 65: c. gen., ἀ. τῶν πλησίον Porph. Sent. 32: c. dat., Eus.Mynd. 1. Adv. -ῶς, c. dat., without harm to, τῇ γαστρί Metrod. 41.
averting or preventing harm, ὕδωρ Theoc. 24.98:—in Pl. Lg. 953b we have the act. and pass. senses conjoined, ἀ. τοῦ δρᾶσαί τε καὶ παθεῖν.

data.ref: Pl. Lg. 953b we have the act. and pass. senses conjoined,

children.definition: without violating the terms, ἀβλαβῶς σπονδαῖς ἐμμένειν, coupled with δικαίως and ἀδόλως, Th. 5.18 and 47 : so in Adj., ξύμμαχοι πιστοὶ . . καὶ ἀ. IG 1.33.
ἀβλαβίῃσι νόοιο h.Merc. 393; Ἀβλαβίαι personified, SIG 1014.67 ( Erythrae); sg. in later Prose, Phld. Piet. 28.

definition: ἀβλαβύνιον σειρὰ πλεκομένη παρʼ Αἰγυπτίοις ἐκ βύβλων <πρὸς> κάθαρσιν οὖσα, Hsch. ἀβλαδέως· ἡδέως, Id. (cf. βλαδαρός). ἀβλάξ· λαμπρῶς ( Cypr.), Id.

children.definition: Nic. Th. 488. Adv. -τως Orph. H. 64.10.

definition: ἄβλαροι ξύλα, Hsch. ἄβλας· ἀσύνετος, Hsch. ( ἀβλής Cyr.).

children.definition: not to run to leaf, Thphr. CP 1.20.5.

children.label: II
children.definition: not to germinate, of seeds, Id. Ign. 44.

not growing out, of fibre, Thphr. HP 1.2.5:—also ἀβλαστ-ής, ές, not growing, ib. 2.2.8; of seeds, not germinating, 8.11.7; of places, unfruitful, ἐδάφη CP 2.4.1; τόποι Gp. 9.9.4 ( Comp.): metaph., ἀ. πρὸς ἀρετήν Plu. Aud. 2.38c; πλοῦτος ἄ. Them. Or. 18.221d.
not striking from cuttings, v.l. Thphr. CP 1.3.2.
unslippered, Opp. C. 4.369, Philostr.Jun. Im. 5.
feeble, Nic. Al. 82; in Lit. Crit. [ τὸ πρᾶγμα] ἀβλεμὲς προσπίπτει falls flat, Longin. 29.1. Adv. ἀβλεμέως, πίνων drinking intemperately, Panyas. 13.8.
mucus, Apollon. Lex. 51.32 (glossed by ἄχυμος); as name of fish, = βελόνη II, Diph.Siph. ap. Ath. 8.355f.
overlook, disregard, τὸ πρέπον Plb. 30.6.4, Anon. ap. Suid.; Pass., τὰ -ηθέντα Hp. Decent. 13.
mistake, oversight, Plb. Fr. 90, Arr. Epict. Fr. 12.
without eyebrows, AP 11.66 ( Antiphil.).
blindness, metaph., Suet. Claud. 39, Hierocl. in CA 25p.477M.: c. gen., failure to see, Polystr. p.31 W.

children.label: II
children.definition: invisibility, PMag.Leid.W. 7.5.

definition: ἄβληρα, i.e. ἄϝληρα, for αὔληρα, εὔληρα (q. v.), Hsch.

children.definition: not thrown or shot, ἰὸν ἀβλῆτα an arrow not yet used, Il. 4.117; cf. A.R. 3.279.
not hit (by missiles), opp. ἀνούτατος, Il. 4.540.
without bleatings, ἐπαύλιον AP 9.149 ( Antip.).
mild, soothing, Nic. Th. 885.

definition: ἀβληχρός, ά, όν, ( α euphon., βληχρός, q.v.):—

children.definition: weak, feeble, of Aphroditeʼs hand, Il. 5.337; τείχεα 8.178; θάνατος an easy death in ripe old age, opp. a violent one, Od. 11.135, 23.282; πόνος Epicur. Sent.Vat. 4; κῶμα A.R. 2.205; πυρετός Procop. Pers. 2.22.
GDI 4986 ( Gortyn), 5125 ( Oaxos), cf. Hsch.

definition: ἀβοατί, ἀβό-ατος, Dor. for ἀβοητί, ἀβόητος.

children.definition: helplessness, LXX Si. 51.10.

admitting of no help, without remedy, incurable, of disease, Hp. Acut. (Sp.) 33; πάθος Plu. Cohib. 2.454d; of wounds, Plb. 1.81.5, etc.; fatal, of poisons, Thphr. HP 9.16.6; ἀ. ἔχειν τὴν ἐπικουρίαν, unserviceable, useless, D.S. 20.42; νὺξ ἀ. Gal. 19.481. Adv. -τως Dsc. Ther. 12, Gal. 5.122.

children.label: II
children.definition: helpless, LXX Ps. 87(88).6, Plu. Arat. 2, Epict. Ench. 24; γυνὴ χήρα καὶ ἀ. BGU 970.8 (ii A. D.).

children.label: III
children.definition: Act., unhelpful, ἀφιλανθρωπία -ήτους ποιεῖ Phld. Oec. p.68J.
without assistance, prob. in Euph. 54.2.
without summons, Pi. N. 8.9.
not loudly lamented, Epigr.Gr. 240 ( Smyrna).
not noised abroad, [ κλέος] οὐκ ὰ. IG 2.4174.

definition: ἀβολαία ( -βαλ- cod.) · συγγραφή, ὁμολογία, Hsch. ἀβολεῖς· περιβολαί (Sicel.), Hsch.

children.definition: meet, A.R. 3.1145; Ep. aor. ἀβόλησαν Id. 2.770, Call. Fr. 455.
a meeting, Ion. word, Antim. [108].
one who meets, Antim. [76].
= Lat. abolla, thick woollen cloak, Peripl.M.Rubr. 6, CPR 1.27 (ii A. D.).
that has not shed his foal-teeth, of a young horse, S. Fr. 408, Pl. Lg. 834c, Stratt. 52, Arist. HA 576b15, IG 2.978: also of an old horse, that no longer sheds them, AB 322.
ἄβολα, τά, an unlucky throw of the dice, Poll. 7.204.
without filth, ψαλὶς οὐκ ἀ. S. Fr. 367 ( -βάρβ- codd.).
= Lat. aborigines, D.H. 1.9, al.
greedy, Hdn.Gr. ap. Sch. Il. 8.178.
unfed, fasting, Nic. Th. 124.
pastureless, ὄρη Babr. 45.10, cf. Eust. 307.27.

definition: ἄβοστοι οἱ αἴτησιν ὑπὸ Λακώνων, Hsch.

children.definition: without pasture, Hsch.
untended: metaph., unheeded, ἀ. τοῦτʼ ἐμῷ φρονήματι A. Supp. 929.
inconsiderately, Suid.:—also -ί, Ph. 1.124.
ill-advised, inconsiderate. Adv. -τως LXX 1 Ma. 5.67.
to be unwilling, Pl. R. 437c: c.acc. inf., Id. Ep. 347a:—c. acc., dislike, object to, D.C. 55.9.

children.label: II
children.definition: not to will, οὐ γὰρ -ῶν ἐνεργεῖ without willing, Plot. 6.8.13, cf. ib. 21.
involuntary, Pl. Lg. 733d, Ph. 1.561; ἀ. καρδίας κίνησις, ἔκκρισις Gal. 2.610, Aët. 13.56. Adv. -τως Asclep. Cypr. ap. Porph. Abst. 4.15, Plu. QConv. 2.631c, S.E. P. 1.19.

children.label: II
children.definition: not according to oneʼs wish or will, τὰ ἀ. Zeno Stoic. 1.53; τύχη Phld. Mort. 33. cf. Ph. 2.392, Plu. Exil. 2.599b.
ill-advisedness, thoughtlessness, Pi. O. 10.41, Hdt. 7.210, Antipho 4.2.6, Men. 16.9D, etc.; ἐπαρθέντες ἀβουλίῃ Hdt. 7.9.γʹ; ἐξ ἀ. πεσεῖν, ἀβουλίᾳ πεσεῖν S. El. 398, 429: pl., A. Th. 750, Hdt. 8.57.
irresolution, Th. 5.75; indecision, Democr. 119.

inconsiderate, ill-advised, S. Ant. 1026, Men. Pk. 382, Anacreont. 12.4; τέκνοισι Ζῆνʼ ἄβουλον taking no thought for them, unfeeling, S. Tr. 140, cf. El. 546, E. Heracl. 152: Comp., Th. 1.120.7: Sup., Plu. Dio 43. Adv. -ως Hdt. 3.71; οὐκ ἀ. Pherecr. 143.6; ἀ. καὶ ἀθέως Antipho 1.23: Sup. ἀβουλότατα Hdt. 7.9.βʹ, Plb. Fr. 92.
without oxen, i.e. poor, Hes. Op. 451.
favourite slave, Men. 64.3, al., LXX Ge. 24.61, Ex. 2.5, al., Plu. Caes. 10, Aristaen. 1.22, Luc. Tox. 14. (Prob. Semitic; written by some Gramm. ἄβρα, cf. AB 322.)

data.ref: Luc. Tox. 14. (Prob. Semitic; written by some Gramm.

definition: ἀβραμίδιον, τό, Dim. of sq., Xenocr. 78.
ἀβραμίς, or ἄβραμις, ιδος, ἡ (also ἀβραβίς, PLond. ined. 2184 (iii A. D.)),

children.definition: mullet, salted in Egypt, Ath. 7.312b, PLond. ined. 2143 (ii A. D.), Opp. H. 1.244.
throw at dice, Hsch. ἀβράνας, Celtic word = κερκοπίθηκος. Id. ἀβρανίδας· κροκευτούς ( Lacon.), Id.
not steeped, στροβίλια PMag.Berol. 1.245.
Hp. Aff. 52, Plu. Isid. 2.381c, Mosch. 2.114.
Hsch. (in Lacon. form -ίδδ-).
of no weight, βάρος μὲν οὐκ ἀβριθές E. Supp. 1125.
wakeful, Hsch., Suid.:— ἀβρίξ, Adv., Hsch.

definition: ἀβρινά κεκαθαρμένα, Hsch. ἀβριστήν· μαστιγίαν, Id.

children.definition: softly or delicately stepping, A. Pers. 1072; Subst. in B. 3.48.
living delicately, effeminate, Ἴωνες B. 17.2, cf. Plu. Demetr. 2 ( Sup.), D.P. 968, Alciphr. 1.12.
wailing womanishly, A. Pers. 541.
luxurious, ἁβρόδαιτι τραπέζῃ Archestr. Fr. 61.1.
luxurious living, a faulty compd., AB 322, Suid, Ael. VH 12.24 (in lemmate).
living delicately, ἁβροδιαίτων Λυδῶν ὄχλος A. Pers. 41, cf. Epigr. ap. Clearch. 4: τὸ ἁ. effeminacy Th. 1.6, Ath. 12.513c; ἁ. βίος, luxurious, Diog.Oen. 23. Adv. -τως Ph. 1.324.
softly clad, Com.Adesp. 1275.
Hsch.
with luxuriant foliage, φοῖνιξ E. Ion 920, IT 1099.

children.label: II
children.definition: with delicate hair, Orph. H. 56.2, Nonn. D. 13.91, al.; (with play on both meanings) AP 12.256 ( Mel.):—also ἁβρό-κομος, ον, Nonn. D. 13.456, Man. 2.446.

data.ref: Nonn. D. 13.91, al.; (with play on both meanings)

children.definition: without Bacchus, AP 6.291 ( Antip.).
with dainty girdle, Hsch.
joining in a shout, Il. 13.41; taken by Aristarch. to mean noisy ( α intens.).
α priv.) noiseless, κῦμα A.R. 4.153.
consisting of delicate maidens, Lyr.Alex.Adesp. 22.
soft-sandalled, Ἔρως AP 12.158 ( Mel.).
with soft leaves, Jo.Gaz. Ecphr. 2.2.
of delicate texture, Lyc. 863.
richly luxuriant, χαίτη E. IT 1148.

definition: ἁβρός, ά, όν, poet. also ός, όν:—

children.definition: graceful, delicate, pretty, παρθένος Hes. Fr. 218; παῖς, Ἔρως Anacr. 17, 65; ἄβραι Χάριτες Sapph. 60; esp. of the body, σῶμα, πούς, etc., Pi. O. 6.55, E. Tr. 506; neut. pl., ἁβρὰ παρηίδος Ph. 1486; of women, A. Fr. 313, S. Tr. 523; ἁ. ἄθυρμα, of a pet dog, IG 14.1647 ( Lipara): of things, splendid, στέφανος, κῦδος, πλοῦτος Pi. I. 8.65, O. 5.7, P. 3.110: of style, graceful, pretty, λόγος Hermog. Id. 2.5; freq. with a notion of disparagement, dainty, luxurious; hence, ἁβρὰ παθεῖν live delicately, Sol. 24.4, Thgn. 474; a common epithet of Asiatics, Hdt. 1.71, etc.; Ἰώνων ἁβρὸς . . ὄχλος Antiph. 91; Ἀγάθυρσοι -ότατοι ἀνδρῶν Hdt. 4.104. Adv. ἁβρῶς, ψάλλειν Anacr. 17; ὑμνεῖν Stesich. 37; βαίνειν step delicately, Sapph. 5, E. Med. 831: neut. sg. as Adv., ἁβρὸν βαίνοντες E. Med. 1164; neut. pl., ἁβρὰ γελᾶν Anacreont. 41.3, 42.5: Comp. ἁβροτέρως, ἔχειν Hld. 1.17.—Chiefly poet., never in old Ep.; rare in early Prose, X. Smp. 4.44, Pl. Smp. 204c, Clearch. 4. [ ᾰ by nature, cf. E. Med. 1164, Tr. 820.]

data.ref: Thgn. 474; a common epithet of Asiatics,

children.definition: dropping rich unguents, μέτωπον Anon. ap. Suid. s.v. ἁβρός.
Sapph. 79, E. Or. 349, Xenoph. 3.1 (pl.).
with delicate ankles, Ναίδες Lyr.Alex.Adesp. 3.3.

miss, c. gen., only in aor. 1 subj., μήπως ἀβροτάξομεν ( Ep. for -ωμεν) ἀλλήλοιϊν Il. 10.65:— Subst. ἀβρόταξις, εως, ἡ, error, Hsch., Eust. 789.52: Adj. ἀβροτήμων, ον, erring, in Hsch., AB 322. (For ἀμṛτάζω, cf. ἀμβροτ-εῖν, ἁμαρτ-εῖν.)

splendour, luxury, δόμους ἁβρότατος houses of luxury, i.e. luxurious, Pi. P. 11.34, cf. B. Fr. 26; τῇ Μήδων στολῇ καὶ ἁβρότητι X. Cyr. 8.8.15, cf. Pl. Alc. 1.122c, E. Ba. 968; οὐκ ἐν ἁβρότητι κεῖσαι thou art not in a position to be fastidious, Id. IA 1343; also, ἁβρότατος ἔπι in the freshness of youth, Pi. P. 8.89.

children.label: II
children.definition: sweetness, charm, Hermog. Id. 1.12.
delicate and costly, προκαλύμματα A. Ag. 690 (lyr.).
Hsch.; cf. ἀβροτάζω.
made of ἀβρότονον, ἔλαιον Dsc. 1.50.
prepared with ἀβρότονον, Dsc. 5.52.

wormwood, Artemisia arborescens, Thphr. HP 6.7.3, Nic. Th. 92, etc.; ἀ. ἄρρεν, southernwood, Artemisia fragrans, Gal. 11.804; ἀ. θῆλυ, lavender cotton, Santolina Chamaecyparissus, Dsc. 3.24; written ἀβούτονον Ps.- Dsc. l.c.
holy, in Hom. only once, νὺξ ἀβρότη Il. 14.78; ἀβρότη alone = νύξ, Eust.ad loc.

children.label: II
children.definition: without men, deserted of men, ἄβροτον εἰς ἐρημίαν v.l. for ἄβατον A. Pr. 2, as quoted by Sch.Ven. Il. 14.78.

children.definition: Anacreont. 41.8.
not to be inundated, BGU 973.14, PFay. 33 (ii A. D.), etc.
want of rain, drought, Men.Eph. ap. J. AJ 8.13.2, Heph. Astr. 1.23, S.E. M. 9.203.
failure of the inundation of the Nile, OGI 56.15 (pl., iii B.C.), cf. CPHerm. 119 ii 22 (iii A. D.).
PFlor. 286.23 (vi A. D.).

definition: ἀβρόχιστος, ον, = foreg., PGoodsp. 15.22 (iv A. D.).

children.definition: unwetted, unmoistened, Aeschin. 2.21, Nic. Th. 339, Sotion p.183 W.; κατὰ πόντον ἄ. ἀΐσσεις Mosch. 2.143 (v.l. ἄτρομος): c. gen., ἅλμης Nonn. D. 1.75. Adv. -χως without getting wet, Lib. Or. 11.217.
wanting rain, waterless, πεδία E. Hel. 1485; Ἀρκαδίη Call. Jov. 19.
not inundated, PHib. 1.85 (iii B. C.), BGU 455 (i A. D.), etc.
in soft tunic, softly clad, AP 9.538; epith. of Dionysus, Inscr.Cos 5.11; εὐνὰς ἁβροχίτωνας beds with soft coverings, A. Pers. 543.

definition: ἅβρυνα ( ἄβρ- Hsch.), τά, mulberries ( Cypr.), Parth. ap. Ath. 2.51f, cf. AB 224.

children.definition: coxcomb, fop, Adam. 1.23.

make delicate, treat delicately, μὴ γυναικὸς ἐν τρόποις ἐμὲ ἅβρυνε A. Ag. 919: deck out, εἰς γάμον ἁβρῦναί τινα AP 6.281 ( Leon.):— Med. or Pass., live delicately; hence, wax wanton, give oneself airs, ἁβρύνεται γὰρ πᾶς τις εὖ πράσσων πλέον A. Ag. 1205, cf. S. OC 1339; ἐκαλλυνόμην τε καὶ ἡβρυνόμην ἄν Pl. Ap. 20c: c. dat. rei, pride, plume oneself on a thing, οὐχ ἁβρύνομαι τῷδʼ E. IA 858; ἡβρύνετο τῷ βραδέως διαπράττειν X. Ages. 9.2; οἷς ὁ τῶν γυναικῶν ἁβρύνεται βίος Clearch. 9.

free from smell, Diph.Siph. ap. Ath. 8.355b, Xenocr. 9, Dsc. 1.16, Aët. 9.1. ( ἄβρομος is a common v.l.)
Abron, an Argive, proverbial for luxurious living, Ἄβρωνος βίος Suid., Zen. 1.4.
not devoured; hence, not bitten by mosquitoes, AP 9.764 ( Paul.Sil.).

Abydos, on the Asiatic side of the Hellespont:— Ἀβυδόθεν, Adv. from Abydos, Il. 4.500; Ἀβυδόθι, at Abydos, 17.584:— Adj. Ἀβυδηνός, ή, όν, of or from Abydos, Ath. 13.572e, etc.: prov., Ἀ. ἐπιφόρημα a dessert of Abydos, i.e. something unpleasant, variously expl., Zen. 1.1, etc.; μὴ εἰκῆ τὴν Ἄβυδον (sc. πατεῖν) Paus.Gr. Fr. 2: Ἀβυδοκόμης ( Ἀβυδηνοκώμης or -κόμος Zen. 1.1), ου, ὁ = ὁ ἐπὶ τῷ συκοφαντεῖν κομῶν, Ar. Fr. 733.

untanned, Sch. Il. 2.527.

well-doing, Eustr. in EN 17.25.

definition: ἀγαθός [ᾰγ], ή, όν, Lacon. ἀγασός Ar. Lys. 1301, Cypr. ἀζαθός GDI 57:—

children.definition: good:

well-born, gentle, opp. κακός, δειλός, οἷά τε τοῖς ἀγαθοῖσι παραδρώωσι χέρηες Od. 15.324, cf. Il. 1.275; ἀφνειός τʼ ἀ. τε Il. 13.664, cf. Od. 18.276; πατρὸς δʼ εἴμʼ ἀγαθοῖο, θεὰ δέ με γείνατο μήτηρ Il. 21.109, cf. Od. 4.611; κακὸς ἐξ ἀ. Thgn. 190, cf. 57 sq.; πραῢς ἀστοῖς, οὐ φθονέων ἀγαθοῖς Pi. P. 3.71, cf. 2.96, 4.285; τίς ἂν εὔπατρις ὧδε βλάστοι; οὐδεὶς τῶν ἀ. κτλ. S. El. 1082; οἵ τʼ ἀ. πρὸς τῶν ἀγενῶν κατανικῶνται Id. Fr. 84; τοὺς εὐγενεῖς γὰρ κἀγαθοὺς . . φιλεῖ Ἄρης ἐναίρειν ib. 649, cf. E. Alc. 600, al.: ἀγαθοὶ καὶ ἐξ ἀγαθῶν Pl. Phdr. 274a:—in political sense, aristocrats, esp. in the phrase καλοὶ κἀγαθοί (v. sub καλοκἀγαθός).

data.quote: κακός, δειλός, οἷά τε τοῖς ἀγαθοῖσι παραδρώωσι χέρηες
πατρὸς δʼ εἴμʼ ἀγαθοῖο, θεὰ δέ με γείνατο μήτηρ
τίς ἂν εὔπατρις ὧδε βλάστοι; οὐδεὶς τῶν ἀ. κτλ.
οἵ τʼ ἀ. πρὸς τῶν ἀγενῶν κατανικῶνται

children.definition: brave, valiant, since courage was attributed to Chiefs and Nobles, Il. 1.131, al.; τῷ κʼ ἀγαθὸς μὲν ἔπεφνʼ, ἀγαθὸν δέ κεν ἐξενάριξεν 21.280; cf. Hdt. 5.109, etc.

data.quote: τῷ κʼ ἀγαθὸς μὲν ἔπεφνʼ, ἀγαθὸν δέ κεν ἐξενάριξεν

children.definition: good, capable, in reference to ability, ἀ. βασιλεύς Il. 3.179; ἰητήρ 2.732; θεράπων 16.165, 17.388; πύκτης Xenoph. 2.15; ἰητρός Hp. Prog. 1; προβατογνώμων A. Ag. 795; ἄρχοντες Democr. 266: freq. with qualifying words, ἀ. ἐν ὑσμίνῃ Il. 13.314; βοὴν ἀ. 2.408, 563, al.; πύξ Od. 11.300; βίην Il. 6.478; γνώμην S. OT 687; πᾶσαν ἀρετήν Pl. Lg. 899b, cf. Alc. 1.124e; τέχνην Id. Prt. 323b; τὰ πολέμια, τὰ πολιτικά, Hdt. 9.122, Pl. Grg. 516b, etc.: more rarely c. dat., ἀ. πολέμῳ X. Oec. 4.15: with Preps., ἄνδρες ἀ. περὶ τὸ πλῆθος Lys. 13.2; εἴς τι Pl. Alc. 1.125a; πρός τι Id. R. 407e: c. inf., ἀ. μάχεσθαι Hdt. 1.136; ἱππεύεσθαι 1.79; ἀ. ἱστάναι good at weighing, Pl. Prt. 356b.

data.ref: Pl. Grg. 516b, etc.: more rarely c. dat.,

children.definition: good, in moral sense, first in Thgn. 438, cf. Heraclit. 104, S. El. 1082, X. Mem. 1.7.1, Pl. Ap. 41d, etc.; ψυχῆς ἀγαθῆς πατρὶς ὁ ξύμπας κόσμος Democr. 247: freq. with other Adjs., ὁ πιστὸς κἀ. S. Tr. 541; δικαίων κἀ. ib. 1050:—ironical, τὸν ἀ. Κρέοντα Id. Ant. 31.

data.quote: ψυχῆς ἀγαθῆς πατρὶς ὁ ξύμπας κόσμος

children.definition: ὦ ἀγαθέ, my good friend, as a term of gentle remonstrance, Pl. Prt. 311a, etc.
ἀ. δαίμων, v. sub δαίμων; ἀ. τύχη, v. sub τύχη; ἀ. θεός = Lat. bona dea, Plu. Caes. 9, Cic. 19.
good, serviceable, Ἰθάκη . . ἀ. κουροτρόφος Od. 9.27, etc.; ἀ. τοῖς τοκεῦσι, τῇ πόλει X. Cyn. 13.17: c. gen., εἴ τι οἶδα πυρετοῦ ἀ. good for it, Id. Mem. 3.8.3; ἑλκῶν Thphr. HP 9.11.1.

αἰδὼς οὐκ ἀ. κεχρημένῳ ἀνδρὶ παρεῖναι Od. 17.347; εἰπεῖν εἰς ἀγαθόν to good purpose, Il. 9.102; ὁ δὲ πείσεται εἰς ἀ. περ for his own good end, 11.789; οὐκ ἀγαθὸν πολυκοιρανίη 2.204:— ἀγαθόν [ἐστι], c. inf., it is good to do so and so, Il. 7.282, 24.130, Od. 3.196, etc.

data.quote: αἰδὼς οὐκ ἀ. κεχρημένῳ ἀνδρὶ παρεῖναι
ὁ δὲ πείσεται εἰς ἀ. περ

children.definition: morally good, πρῆξις Democr. 177; ἔργα Emp. 112.2, cf. Ep.Rom. 2.7, etc.

ἀγαθόν, τό, good, blessing, benefit, of persons or things, ὦ μέγα ἀ. σὺ τοῖς φίλοις X. Cyr. 5.3.20; φίλον, ὃ μέγιστον ἀ. εἶναί φασι Id. Mem. 2.4.2, cf. Ar. Ra. 74, etc; as term of endearment for a baby, blessing!, treasure!, Men. Sam. 28:— ἀγαθόν τινα δεδρακέναι, πεποιηκέναι confer a benefit on . . , Th. 3.68, Lys. 13.92; ἐπʼ ἀγαθῷ τινος for oneʼs good, Th. 5.27, X. Cyr. 7.4.3; ἐπʼ ἀ. τοῖς πολίταις Ar. Ra. 1487; οὐκ ἐπʼ ἀ. for no good end, Th. 1.131; ἐπʼ οὐδενὶ ἀ. τῆς Ἑλλάδος X. HG 5.2.35:—in pl., ἡ ἐπʼ ἀγαθοῖς γεναμένη (sic) κατασπορά PFlor. 21.10 (iii A.D.):— τὸ ἀ. or τἀ., the good, Epich. 171.5, cf. Pl. R. 506b, 508e, Arist. Metaph. 1091a31, etc.:—in pl., ἀγαθά, τά, goods of fortune, treasures, wealth, Hdt. 2.172, Lys. 13.91, X. Mem. 1.2.63, etc.; ἀγαθὰ πράττειν fare well, Ar. Av. 1706; also, good things, dainties, Thgn. 1000, Ar. Ach. 873, etc.: good qualities, τοῖς ἀ., οἷς ἔχομεν ἐν τῇ ψυχῇ Isoc. 8.32, cf. Democr. 37; good points, of a horse, εἰ τἄλλα πάντα ἀ. ἔχοι, κακόπους δʼ εἴη X. Eq. 1.2.

data.quote: ὦ μέγα ἀ. σὺ τοῖς φίλοις
φίλον, ὃ μέγιστον ἀ. εἶναί φασι

data.ref: Ar. Ra. 74, etc; as term of endearment for a baby,

data.quote: τοῖς ἀ., οἷς ἔχομεν ἐν τῇ ψυχῇ
εἰ τἄλλα πάντα ἀ. ἔχοι, κακόπους δʼ εἴη

Comp. ἀμείνων, ἀρείων, βελτίων, κρείσσων (κάρρων) , λωΐων ( λὥων), Ep. βέλτερος, λωΐτερος, φέρτερος:— Sup. ἄριστος, βέλτιστος, κράτιστος, λώϊστος ( λῷστος), Ep. βέλτατος, κάρτιστος, φέρτατος, φέριστος:— later, reg. Comp. ἀγαθώτερος LXX Jd. 11.25, 15.2, D.S. 8 Fr. 12, Plot. 5.5.9, Diod.Rh. p.53.9H.: Sup. ἀγαθώτατος D.S. 16.85, Hld. 5.15, etc. ( -ότατος POxy. 1757.26 (ii A.D.)).

goodness, kindness, LXX Jd. 9.16, al., Ep.Rom. 15.14, Ep.Eph. 5.9.

transport of joy, LXX Ps. 31(32).7, etc.
great joy, exultation, LXX Jb. 8.21, al., Ev.Luc. 1.14, 44, I Enoch 5.9, Ps.-Callisth. 2.22.

rejoice exceedingly, Apoc. 19.7 (v.l. ἀγαλλιώμεθα) ; ἠγαλλίᾱσα Ev.Luc. 1.47, cf. POxy. 1592.4 (iii/iv A.D.):—more common as Dep. ἀγαλλιάομαι, LXX Is. 12.6, al.: fut. -άσομαι Ps. 5.11: aor. ἠγαλλιᾱσάμην Ps. 15(16).2, Ev.Jo. 8.56; ἠγαλλιάσθην ib. 5.35.—This family of words seems also to have been used in malam partem, ἀγαλλιάζει· λοιδορεῖται, ἀγάλλιος· λοίδορος, ἀγαλμός· λοιδορία, Hsch., cf. EM 7.8.

definition: ἀγάλλω [ᾰ], Pi. O. 1.86b, Ar. Th. 128, etc.: fut. ἀγᾰλῶ Ar. Pax 399, Theopomp.Com. 47: aor. ἤγηλα D.C. 44.48, etc., subj. ἀγήλω Hermipp. 8, inf. ἀγῆλαι E. Med. 1027:— Pass., only pres. and impf. in early writers: aor. 1 inf. ἀγαλθῆναι D.C. 51.20:—

children.definition: glorify, exalt, Pi. l.c., N. 5.43: esp. pay honour to a god, ἄγαλλε Φοῖβον Ar. Th. 128, cf. Pl. Lg. 931a; ἀ. τινὰ θυσίαισι Ar. Pax l.c.; φέρε νῦν, ἀγήλω τοὺς θεούς Hermipp. l.c.; θεοὺς καρποῖς Xenocr. ap. Porph. Abst. 4.22:— adorn, γαμηλίους εὐνάς E. l.c.:— Med. in act. sense, εὔιον ἀγαλλόμεναι θεόν E. Ba. 157:— Pass., glory, exult in a thing, c. part., τεύχεα δʼ Ἕκτωρ . . ἔχων ὤμοισιν ἀγάλλεται Il. 17.473; νικῶν Archil. 66.4; ἣν ἕκαστος πατρίδα ἔχων . . ἀ. Th. 4.95; but mostly c. dat., ἵπποισιν καὶ ὄχεσφιν ἀγαλλόμενος Il. 12.114; πτερύγεσσι 2.462; νῆες . . ἀ. Διὸς οὔρῳ Od. 5.176; Μοῦσαι . . ἀ. ὀπὶ καλῇ Hes. Th. 68; ἀσπίδι Archil. 6; ἑορταῖς E. Tr. 452: in Prose, τῷ οὐνόματι ἠγάλλοντο Hdt. 1.143, cf. Th. 2.44, Pl. Tht. 176b; ἀλλοτρίοις πτεροῖς ἀ. strut in borrowed plumes, Luc. Apol. 4; ἐπί τινι Th. 3.82, X. Cyr. 8.4.11; διὰ τἆλλα καὶ ὅτι . . D.C. 66.2: c. acc., AP 7.378 ( Apollonid.): abs., Hdt. 4.64, 9.109, Hp. Art. 35, E. Ba. 1197.

data.quote: τεύχεα δʼ Ἕκτωρ . . ἔχων ὤμοισιν ἀγάλλεται

definition: ἄγαλμα, ατος, τό, acc. to Hsch. πᾶν ἐφʼ ᾧ τις ἀγάλλεται,

children.definition: glory, delight, honour, Il. 4.144, etc.; κεφάλαισιν ἄνδρων ἀγάλματα (sc. λόφοι) Alc. 15; χώρας ἄ., of an ode, Pi. N. 3.13, cf. 8.16; of children, τέκνον δόμων ἄ. A. Ag. 208; εὐκλείας τέκνοις ἄ. conversely, of a father, S. Ant. 704; Καδμεΐας νύμφας ἄ., addressed to Bacchus, ib. 1115; ματέρος ἄ. φόνιον, of slain sons, E. Supp. 371; ἀγάλματʼ ἀγορᾶς mere ornaments of the agora, Id. El. 388, cf. Metagen. 10.3; rare in Prose, Pl. Ti. 37c.

pleasing gift, esp. for the gods, ἄ. θεῶν Od. 8.509, of a bull adorned for sacrifice, ib. 3.438; of a tripod, Hdt. 5.60, al.; generally, = ἀνάθημα, IG 1.37312a, etc.; Χάρης εἰμὶ . . ἄ. τοῦ Ἀπόλλωνος GDI 5507 ( Miletus); ἄνθηκεν ἄ. Simon. 155; so, Ἑκάτης ἄ . . . κύων, because sacred to her, E. Fr. 968, = Ar. Fr. 594a; ἄ. Ἀΐδα, of a tombstone, Pi. N. 10.67.

statue in honour of a god, Hdt. 1.131, 2.42, 46, Lys. 6.15 (pl.):— τὸ τοῦ Διὸς ἄ., opp. εἰκόνες of men, Isoc. 9.57, cf. Michel 545 ( Phrygia, ii B.C.), etc.; as an object of worship, A. Th. 258, Eu. 55, S. OT 1379, Pl. Phdr. 251a:— sculpture, μήτε ἄ. μήτε γραφή Arist. Pol. 1336b15.
statue (more general than ἀνδριάς, q.v.), Pl. Men. 97d, etc.:—also, portrait, picture, ἐξαλειφθεῖσʼ ὡς ἄ. E. Hel. 262.
image, τῶν ἀιδίων θεῶν Pl. Ti. 37c; νεφέλης E. Hel. 705; μητρός Trag.Adesp. 126; Ἄρεως Polemo Call. 52:—expressed by painting or words, Pl. Smp. 216e, cf. R. 517d; hieroglyphic sign, Plot. 5.8.6.

eagle-wood, Aquilaria malaccensis, Dsc. 1.22, etc.

definition: ἄγαμαι [ᾰ], 2 pl. ἄγασθε Od. 5.129, Ep. ἀγάασθε ib. 119; Ep. inf. ἀγάασθαι 16.203: impf. ἠγάμην Pl. R. 367e, X. Smp. 8.8, Ep. 2 pl. ἠγάασθε Od. 5.122: fut. Ep. ἀγάσσομαι Od. 4.181; later, ἀγασθήσομαι Them. Or. 27.337b, Themist. Ep. 8: aor. ἠγασάμην Hom. D. 18.204, Plu. Fab. 18, etc.; Ep. ἠγάσσατο or ἀγάσσατο Il. 3.181, 224; after Hom. the pass. ἠγάσθην prevails, Hes. Fr. 93.2, Sol. 33, etc. (Perh. cognate with ἀγα-, q.v.) [ ᾰγᾰμαι, but ἠγᾱασθε metri grat., Od. l.c.]

Il. 8.29; τὸ προορᾶν ἄ. σευ Hdt. 9.79; ὑμέων ἀγάμεθα τὴν προνοίην Id. 8.144; οὐκ ἄγαμαι ταῦτʼ ἀνδρὸς ἀριστέως E. IA 28; ταῦτα ἀγασθείς X. Cyr. 2.3.19, cf. Isoc. 4.84, etc.: c. acc. pers. et gen. rei, admire one for a thing, Pl. R. 426d, X. Cyr. 2.3.21.

part., wonder at oneʼs doing, ἄ. Ἐρασίνου οὐ προδιδόντος Hdt. 6.76.β; ἀ. αὐτοῦ εἰπόντος Pl. R. 329d, etc.; ἄ. τινος ὅτι, . . διότι . . , Id. Hp.Ma. 291e, X. Mem. 4.2.9, etc.

Fr. 216 (attributed to Chilo by Arist. Rh. 1389b4); μηδὲν ἄ. σπεύδειν Thgn. 335:—with Verbs, ἄ. διαστρέψαι Hp. Fract. 8; ἄ. ἐλευθεροστομεῖς A. Pr. 182; ἄ. τι ποιεῖν Pl. Ph. 1327:— Med. in abs. sense, show signs of love, caress, κύνεον ἀγαπαζόμενοι κεφαλήν τε καὶ ὤμους Od. 21.224: c. acc., like Act., Pi. P. l.c.; τινὰ δώροις A.R. 4.416.

definition: ἀγαπάω ( Dor. ἀγαπ-έω Archyt. ap. Stob. 3.1.110), Ep. aor. ἀγάπησα Od. 23.214: pf. ἠγάπηκα Isoc. 15.147, etc.

children.label: I
children.definition: greet with affection (cf. foreg.), once in Hom., Od. l.c.:—in Trag. only show affection for the dead, ὅτʼ ἠγάπα νεκρούς E. Supp. 764, cf. Hel. 937:— Pass., to be regarded with affection, ξένων εὐεργεσίαις ἀγαπᾶται Pi. I. 5(6).70:— generally, love, ὥσπερ . . οἱ ποιηταὶ τὰ αὑτῶν ποιήματα καὶ οἱ πατέρες τοὺς παῖδας ἀγαπῶσι Pl. R. 330c, cf. Lg. 928a; ὡς λύκοι ἄρνʼ ἀγαπῶσʼ Poet. ap. Phdr. 241d; ἀ. τοὺς ἐπαινέτας ib. 257e; ἐπιστήμην, τὰ χρήματα, etc., Id. Phlb. 62d, al.; τούτους ἀγαπᾶ καὶ περὶ αὑτὸν ἔχει D. 2.19; ὁ μέγιστον ἀγαπῶν διʼ ἐλάχιστʼ ὀργίζεται Men. 659; esp. of children, αὐτὸν ἐτιθηνούμην ἀγαπῶσα Id. Sam. 32, etc.:— Pass., Pl. Plt. 301d, etc.; ὑπὸ τῶν θεῶν ἠγαπῆσθαι D. 61.9; ὑπὸ τοῦ φθᾶ OGI 90.4 ( Rosetta, ii B. C.); so in LXX of the love of God for man and of man for God, Is. 41.8, De. 11.1, al., cf. Ev.Jo. 3.21, Ep.Rom. 8.28:—as dist. fr. φιλέω (q. v.) implying regard rather than affection, but the two are interchanged, cf. X. Mem. 2.7.9 and 12; φιλεῖσθαι defined as ἀγαπᾶσθαι αὐτὸν διʼ αὑτόν Arist. Rh. 1371a21:—seldom of sexual love, for ἐράω, Arist. Fr. 76, Luc. JTr. 2; ἀ. ἑταίραν Anaxil. 22.1 (but ἀ. ἑταίρας to be fond of them, X. Mem. 1.5.4; ἐρωτικὴν μέμψιν ἡ ἀγαπωμένη λύει dub. in Democr. 271):—of brotherly love, Ev.Matt. 5.43, al.

data.quote: ὥσπερ . . οἱ ποιηταὶ τὰ αὑτῶν ποιήματα καὶ οἱ πατέρες τοὺς παῖδας ἀγαπῶσι
τούτους ἀγαπᾶ καὶ περὶ αὑτὸν ἔχει
ὁ μέγιστον ἀγαπῶν διʼ ἐλάχιστʼ ὀργίζεται

v.l. in h.Ap. 515, ( ἀγᾱ-) Theoc. 1.126.

definition: ἀγαυός, ή, όν, in Hom. almost always of kings or heroes,

children.definition: illustrious, noble, κήρυκες Il. 3.268; Περσεφόνεια Od. 11.213; πομπῆες noble guides, 13.71, cf. Pi. P. 4.72; once in Trag., Πέρσαις ἀγαυοῖς A. Pers. 986 (lyr.): Sup. -ότατος Od. 15.229.
brilliant, glorious, δῶρον h.Merc. 442; θρόος Pi. Pae. 9.36; esp. of stars, Arat. 71, al., Man. 2.14 ( Sup.):—in late Prose, Hierocl. in CA 4p.425M. (Perh. α intens., γαίω, cf. Hdn.Gr. 2.166.)
insolence, LXX Ba. 4.34, Hsch., AB 325.
to be insolent, LXX Jb. 3.14: Act., EM 6.38.

definition: ἀγαύρισμα, τό, kind of wrestling, Eust. 1444.8.

children.definition: α euphon., stately, proud, ταῦρος Hes. Th. 832; δένδρον Nic. Th. 832 ( Sup.). Adv. Sup. -ότατα Hdt. 7.57. β.
Ion., euphem. for a beggar, EM 6.30, Suid.
loud-sounding, ἀοιδαί Pi. O. 6.91.
Alcm. 121.
daily stages of the ἄγγαροι, EM 7.17.
impressment for the public service, OGI 665.21 (pl.), cf. Arr. Epict. 4.1.79; in pl. = cursus publicus, SIG 880.53 ( Pizus, iii A. D.).
one who impresses, Hsch. s.v. ἀγγαρεύεται.

children.label: II
children.definition: impressed workman, labourer, PSI 200.2 (vi A. D.); ὁ ἐπικείμενος τῶν ἀ. PIand. 24.1 (vi A. D.).

press one to serve as an ἄγγαρος, generally, press into service, Ev.Matt. 5.41, 27.32, OGI 665.24; κτήνη, πλοῖα PTeb. 5.182, 252 (ii B. C.), cf. PPetr. 2p.64 (iii B. C.):— Pass., to be pressed into service, Men. 440: metaph., to be constrained, Procop. Arc. 13.

definition: ἀγγαρήϊος, ὁ, Ion. form of ἄγγαρος, Hdt. 3.126.

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst. ἀγγᾰρ-ήϊον, τό, posting-system, Id. 8.98.
mounted courier, for carrying royal dispatches, Hdt. 3.126, X. Cyr. 8.6.17, Theopomp. Hist. 106, etc.
ἄ. ὄλεθρος Men. 2 D., cf. Lib. Or. 1.129.

children.label: II
children.definition: Adj., ἄ. πῦρ the courier flame, of beacon fires, A. Ag. 282; ἄ. ἡμίονοι posting-mules, Lib. Or. 18.143. (Assyr. agarru, ‘hired labourer’.)
bear as an ἄγγαρος, Procop. Arc. 30, Aed. 2.4; generally, ‘toil and moil’, Men. 10D.

definition: ἄγγατος τὸ εἰς ἀναδενδράδα ξύλον, Hsch.
ἀγγείδιον, τό, Dim. of ἀγγεῖον. Thphr. HP 9.6.4, Hero Spir. 1.6, Damocr. ap. Gal. 13.41 (prob. l.), BGU 590.8 (ii A. D.).

children.label: II
children.definition: gallbladder, Ruf. Anat. 30.
take up a vein and operate upon it, c. acc., interp. in Sor. 1.85, cf. Paul.Aeg. 6.5

senses.definition: Subst. ἀγγειο-λογία, ἡ, Antyll. or Heliod. ap. Orib. 45.18.32, Aët. 7.95.

children.definition: vessel for holding liquid or dry substances ( τοῦτο . . ξηροῖς καὶ ὑγροῖς . . ἐργασθέν, ἀγγεῖον ὃ δὴ μιᾷ κλήσει προσφθεγγόμεθα Pl. Plt. 287e); of metal, ἀργύρεα ἀ. silver jars or vases for water, Hdt. 1.188; ἀργυρᾶ καὶ χαλκᾶ ἀ. Plu. QConv. 2.695b; ἐν ἀ. χαλκῷ mortar, Thphr. Lap. 60; ξύλινα ἀ. tubs, Hdt. 4.2; vessels for holding money, in a treasury, Id. 2.121.βʹ; for masons’ use, Th. 4.4; ὀστράκινα ἀ. Hp. Mul. 2.193, LXX La. 4.2; pails or buckets used by firemen, Plu. Rom. 20; sacks of leather, θύλακοι καὶ ἄλλα ἀ. X. An. 6.4.23; τὰς ῥαφὰς τῶν ἀ. Plu. Lys. 16; for corn, LXX Ge. 42.25; for wine, LXX 1 Ki. 25.18; for bread, 1 Ki. 9.7; box for petitions, PTaur. I ii 6 (ii B. C.), etc.

data.quote: τοῦτο . . ξηροῖς καὶ ὑγροῖς . . ἐργασθέν, ἀγγεῖον ὃ δὴ μιᾷ κλήσει προσφθεγγόμεθα

children.definition: receptacle, reservoir, X. Oec. 9.2, Pl. Lg. 845e; bed of the sea, Pl. Criti. 111a.
coffin, sarcophagus, IG 12(2).494 ( Lesbos), BSA 17.227 (Pamphyl.), etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: vessel, cavity, Hp. Morb. 4.37, Arist. HA 521b6, PA 680b33; of the veins, Id. HA 511b17, al.; the lungs, Id. GA 787b3; the female breast, Id. PA 692a12; afterbirth, Sor. 2.57; of plants, capsule, Thphr. HP 1.11.1:—later, the body itself, M.Ant. 3.3, cf. Secund. Sent. 7.
section of a vein, Paul.Aeg. 6.31.
like a vessel, hollow, Arist. PA 671a23, Eudem. Fr. 44, M.Ant. 10.38.

definition: ἀγγελία, Ion. and Ep. ἀγγελίη, ἡ, ( ἄγγελος)

children.definition: message, tidings, as well the substance as the conveyance thereof, Il. 18.17, Od. 2.30, etc.; ἀ. λέγουσα τάδε Hdt. 2.114; ἀγγελίην φάτο, ἀπόφασθε, ἀπέειπε, Il. 18.17, 9.422, 7.416; φέρειν 15.174; πέμπειν Hdt. 2.114; ἐσπέμπειν 3.69; τὰς ἀ. ἐσφέρειν 1.114, 3.77:— ἐμὴ ἀ. a report of me, concerning me, Il. 19.337; ἀ. τινός a message about a person or thing, ἀγγελίην πατρὸς φέρει ἐρχομένοιο news of thy fatherʼs coming, Od. 1.408; ἀνέρος αἴθονος ἀ. S. Aj. 222; ἀ. τῆς Χίου ἀφικνεῖται Th. 8.15; ἦλθε ἀ. τῶν πόλεων ὅτι ἀφεστᾶσι Id. 1.61: ἀ. ἦλθον ἐκ τῶν πολεμίων X. Cyr. 6.2.14; with Verbs of motion, ἀγγελίην ἐλθεῖν Il. 11.140: Ep. in gen., τευ ἀγγελίης . . ἤλυθες Il. 13.252; ἀγγελίης οἴχνεσκε 15.640; ἤλυθε σεῦ ἕνεκʼ ἀγγελίης (i.e. ἀγγελίης σοῦ ἕνεκα) 3.206; ἀγγελίης πωλεῖται Hes. Th. 781:—wrongly expl. by Sch. Il., Apollon. Lex. as a masc. Subst. ἀγγελίης.

data.quote: ἦλθε ἀ. τῶν πόλεων ὅτι ἀφεστᾶσι

children.definition: announcement, proclamation, Pi. P. 2.4: command, order, h.Cer. 448, Pi. O. 3.28, cf. Od. 5.150, 7.263.
Ἀ. personified as daughter of Hermes, Pi. O. 8.82.

children.label: II
children.definition: messenger, Ἶρις ἀ. v.l. Hes. Th. 781.
bear messages, Sch. A. Pr. 969.
messenger, Hdt. 1.120, Arist. Mu. 398a31, Luc. Sacr. 8, etc.: esp. Persian chamberlain, Hdt. 3.118.
of or for a messenger, ῥῆσις Phryn. PS p.45B.

children.label: b
children.definition: conveying information, πάθος, of sensation, Gal. 19.378.
angelic, τάξις, νοῦς Procl. in Ti. 1.341, 3.126 D.; γένος Hierocl. in CA 2p.423M. Adv. -κῶς Procl. in Ti. 3.192 D.: opp. δαιμονίως, Id. in Cra. p.71 P.

children.label: II
children.definition: ἀ. ὄρχησις Sicilian pantomimic dance at banquets, Ath. 14.629e, cf. Poll. 4.103, and v. ἄγγελος II; perh. from Ἄγγελος a name of Hecate, cf. Ath. l.c., Poll. l.c., Hsch.

data.ref: Poll. 4.103, and v. ἄγγελος II; perh. from

children.definition: messenger, h.Merc. 296, Call. Jov. 68, Hec. 1.1.6, Nonn. D. 13.36: fem. ἀγγελιῶτις, ιδος, Call. Del. 216.

definition: ἀγγέλλω, ( ἄγγελος): impf. ἀγγέλλεσκον Hsch.: Ep. and Ion. fut. ἀγγελέω Il. 9.617, Hdt., Att. ἀγγελῶ, Dor. -ίω ( ἀν-) Tab.Heracl. 1.118: aor. 1 ἤγγειλα Hom., Att.: pf. ἤγγελκα Plb. 35.4.2, ( κατ-) Lys. 25.30, ( εἰσ-) Lycurg. 1, ( περι-) D. 21.4:— Med. (v. infra): aor. ἠγγείλαμην ( ἐπ-) Hdt. 6.35, Pl. Grg. 458d:— Pass., fut. ἀγγελθήσομαι ( ἀπ-) D. 19.324, later ἀγγελήσομαι ( ἀν-) LXX Ps. 21(22).30: aor. ἠγγέλθην Hdt., Att.: pf. ἤγγελμαι A. Ch. 774, Th. 8.97: plpf. ἄγγελτο v.l. in Hdt. 7.37:— aor. 2 Pass. ἠγγέλην is found IG 1.27b ( ἐπ-), E. IT 932, and became usual in Hellenistic Gk., cf. LXX Jo. 2.2 ( ἀπ-), Plu. Ant. 68, Hdn. 3.7.1, etc.: aor. 2 Act. ἤγγελον is rare even in late writers, as ( παρ-) App. BC 1.121 without impf. as v.l., though in AP 7.614 ( Agath.) ἀγγελέτην is required by the metre:—

children.definition: bear a message, ὦρτο δὲἾρις . . ἀγγελέουσα Il. 8.409; τινί Od. 4.24, 15.458: c. inf., οἵ κε . . κείνοις ἀγγείλωσι . . οἶκόνδε νέεσθαι may bring them word to return home, 16.350, cf. EM 6.52: c. acc. inf., κήρυκες δʼ . . ἀγγελλόντων . . γέροντας λέξασθαι Il. 8.517.

announce, report, ἐσθλά Il. 10.448; φάος ἠοῦς Od. 13.94; Ποσειδάωνι πάντα τάδε Il. 15.159:—in Prose, μή τι νεώτερον ἀγγέλλεις ; Pl. Prt. 310b; prov., οὐ πόλεμον ἀγγέλλεις ‘thatʼs good news’, Id. Phdr. 242b; ἀγγέλλωμεν ἐς πόλιν τάδε ; E. Or. 1539; πρὸς τίνʼ ἀγγεῖλαί με χρὴ λόγους ; Id. Supp. 399.

data.quote: πρὸς τίνʼ ἀγγεῖλαί με χρὴ λόγους ;

children.definition: bring news of . . , εἴ κέ μιν ἀγγείλαιμι Od. 14.120; later, ἀ. περί τινος S. El. 1111:—dependent clauses are added with a Conj., ἤγγειλʼ ὅττι ῥά οἱ πόσις ἔκτοθι μίμνε Il. 22.439; ἀ. ὡς . . E. IT 704, D. 18.169; ὁθούνεκα . . S. El. 47:—also in part., ἦ καὶ θανόντʼ ἤγγειλαν; ib. 1452; Κῦρον ἐπιστρατεύοντα . . ἤγγειλεν X. An. 2.3.19, cf. Cyr. 6.2.15; with ὡς, πατέρα τὸν σὸν ἀγγελῶν ὡς οὐκέτʼ ὄντα S. OT 955; ἤγγειλας ὡς τεθνηκότα Id. El. 1341.

data.quote: ἤγγειλʼ ὅττι ῥά οἱ πόσις ἔκτοθι μίμνε
ὡς, πατέρα τὸν σὸν ἀγγελῶν ὡς οὐκέτʼ ὄντα

children.label: II
children.definition: Med., only pres., Τεύκρῳ ἀγγέλλομαι εἶναι φίλος I announce myself to him as a friend, Id. Aj. 1376.

children.label: III
children.definition: Pass., to be reported of, ἐπὶ τὸ πλεῖον Th. 6.34: c. part., ζῶν ἢ θανὼν ἀγγέλλεται S. Tr. 73, cf. E. Hec. 591, Th. 3.16, X. HG 4.3.13: c. inf., ἤγγελται ἡ μάχη ἰσχυρὰ γεγονέναι Pl. Chrm. 153b, cf. X. Cyr. 5.3.30:— ἠγγέλθη τοῖς στρατηγοῖς, ὅτι φεύγοιεν that . . , Id. HG 1.1.27:— ἐπὶ τοῖς ἠγγελμένοις Th. 8.97. ( ἀπ-αγγέλλω is more common in Oratt.)
message, tidings, E. Or. 876, Th. 7.74, etc.
messenger, envoy, Il. 2.26, etc.; διʼ ἀγγέλων ὁμιλέειν τινί Hdt. 5.92.ζʹ, cf. SIG 229.25 ( Erythrae):— prov., Ἀράβιος ἄ., of a loquacious person, Men. 32.

one that announces or tells, e.g. of birds of augury, Il. 24.292, 296; Μουσῶν ἄγγελος, of a poet, Thgn. 769; ἄγγελε ἔαρος . . χελιδοῖ Simon. 74; ἄ. ἄφθογγος, of a beacon, Thgn. 549; of the nightingale, ὄρνις . . Διὸς ἄ. S. El. 149: c. gen. rei, ἄ. κακῶν ἐμῶν Id. Ant. 277; ἄγγελον γλῶσσαν λόγων E. Supp. 203; αἴσθησις ἡμῖν ἄ. Plot. 5.3.3; neut. pl., ἄγγελα νίκης Nonn. D. 34.226.
angel, LXX Ge. 28.12, al., Ev.Matt. 1.24, al., Ph. 2.604, etc.

semi-divine being, ἡλιακοὶ ἄ. Jul. Or. 4.141b, cf. Iamb. Myst. 2.6, Procl. in R. 2.243 K.; ἄ. καὶ ἀρχάγγελοι Theol.Ar. 43.10, cf. Dam. Pr. 183, al.: also in mystical and magical writings, Herm. ap. Stob. 1.49.45, PMag.Lond. 46.121, etc.

data.ref: Dam. Pr. 183, al.: also in mystical and magical writings,

children.label: II
children.definition: Hsch.

definition: ἀγγέλτειρα, ἡ, fem., = foreg., prob. in Orph. H. 78.3.

children.definition: premonitory: c. gen., τεράστια συμφορᾶς ἀ. Heracl. Alleg. 42; τοῦ μέλλοντος Porph. Abst. 3.3: ἀ. ζῴδια Jul.Laod. in Cat.Cod.Astr. 5(1).192.

definition: ἀγγέριος ἄγγελος, Hsch. ἀγγεράκομον· σταφυλήν, Id.

children.definition: receptacle for vessels, Ath. 5.21cc, cf. ἐγγυθήκη.

definition: ἀγγοπήνια τὰ τῶν μελισσῶν κηρία. Hsch., Suid. ἀγγόρπη· ᾧ τοὺς ἐλέφαντας τύπτουσι σιδήρῳ, Hsch.

children.definition: vessel to hold liquids, e.g. wine, Od. 16.13, cf. 2.289; milk, Il. 16.643; vat for the vintage, Hes. Op. 613; pitcher, Hdt. 5.12, E. El. 55; bucket, pail, Hdt. 4.62; wine-bowl, E. IT 953, 960.

children.label: II
children.definition: cradle, Hdt. 1.113, E. Ion 32, 1337; casket, S. Tr. 622; cinerary urn, Id. El. 1118, 1205; coffin, CIG 3573 ( Assos).

children.label: III
children.definition: womb, Hp. Epid. 6.5.11, v. Gal. ad loc.; τρόφιμον ἄ. stomach, Tim. Pers. 73.

children.label: IV
children.definition: shell of the κάραβος, Opp. H. 2.406.

children.label: V
children.definition: cell of a honey-comb, AP 9.226 ( Zonas).

cake or tart, Hsch. ἀγγριάς· τοὺς ἐρεθισμούς· οἱ δὲ τὰς ἀνίας, Orion ap. EM 6.49, cf. Hsch. ἀγγρίζειν· ὑφαιρεῖσθαι (cf. ἀγρέω) , ἐρεθίζειν, Hsch., EM 7.28. ἀγγρίς· ὀδύνη, Suid. ἀγγρισμός, irritatio, Gloss.
irritator, Gloss.
Frankish javelin, Agath. 2.5.
by carrying, ἄγδην σύρειν Luc. Lex. 10.

definition: ἄγε, ἄγετε, imper. of ἄγω, used as Adv.,

children.definition: come on! freq. in Hom., who mostly strengthens it, εἰ δʼ ἄγε, νῦν δʼ ἄγε, ἄγε δή, ἀλλʼ ἄγε, in Att. freq. ἄγε νύν Ar. Eq. 1011, etc.; before 1 and 2 pers. pl., ἄγε δὴ τραπείομεν Il. 3.441; ἄγε δὴ στέωμεν 11.348; ἄγε τάμνετε Od. 3.332; ἀλλʼ ἄγε, Πέρσαι, φροντίδα θώμεθα A. Pers. 140; ἄγε δὴ καὶ χορὸν ἅψωμεν Id. Eu. 307; rarely before 1 sg., ἄγε δὴ . . ἀριθμήσω Od. 13.215; before 3 pl., ἀλλʼ ἄγε, κήρυκες . . λαὸν . . ἀγειρόντων Il. 2.437; in Prose, ἄγε τοίνυν . . σκοπῶμεν X. Cyr. 5.5.15; foll. by ὅπως c. fut., Ar. Ec. 149; abs., E. Cyc. 590:—also, ἄγετε, . . λύσασθε A. Ch. 803; ἄγετε with 1 pl., Il. 2.139, Od. 1.76, Ar. Lys. 665; with 1 sg., Od. 22.139: cf. ἄγι.
speechless, πέτρα Epigr. in AEM 6.6 ( Callatis).
sacrificial victim, GDI 1266 (Pamphyl.).
landless, corrupt in A. Supp. 858.

definition: ἀγείρατος, ον, poet. for ἀγέραστος, Hdn. Gr. 2.269.

ἀγείρω, Aeol. ἀγέρρω EM 8.13: fut. ἀγερῶ IG 5(1).1447.16 ( Messene, ii B. C.): aor. 1 ἤγειρα, Ep. ἄγειρα Od. 14.285:— Med., aor. 1 ἠγειράμην A.R 4.1335, ( συν-) Od. 14.323, Ael. VH 4.14:— Pass., aor. 1 ἠγέρθην Hom.: pf. ἀγήγερμαι App. BC 2.134: plpf. ἀγήγερτο Id. Mith. 108, Ep. 3 pl. ἀγηγέρατο Il. 4.211, App. Hisp. 40.— Hom. has shortened pres. ἀγέρεσθαι (al. ἀγερέσθαι) Od. 2.385 (also in later Ep., A.R. 3.895, etc., cf. IG 14.1389 i 35), aor. 2 ἀγέροντο Il. 18.245, part. ἀγρόμενος 2.481, etc.:—

children.definition: gather together, λαὸν ἀγείρων Il. 4.377, etc.; ἐνθάδʼ ἀπὸ . . πολίων ἤγειρα ἕκαστον 17.222; so in Att., τὸν ἐς Θήβας στόλον S. OC 1306, Th. 1.9; τὸ Ἑλλάδος στράτευμα S. El. 695; στρατιάν X. An. 3.2.13, cf. App. Mith. 84; εἰς μίαν οἴκησιν ἀ. κοινωνούς Pl. R. 369c:— Pass., gather, assemble, Il. 2.52, Od. 2.8, etc.; ἀγρόμενοι σύες herded swine, Od. 16.3; θυμὸς ἐνὶ στήθεσσιν ἀγέρθη, ἐς φρένα θυμὸς ἀγέρθη Il. 4.152, 22.475 (cf. ἐγείρω).

data.quote: θυμὸς ἐνὶ στήθεσσιν ἀγέρθη, ἐς φρένα θυμὸς ἀγέρθη

children.label: II
children.definition: collect, gather, δημόθεν ἄλφιτα . . καὶ αἴθοπα οἶνον ἀγείρας Od. 19.197; πολὺν βίοτον καὶ χρυσὸν ἀγείρων 3.301; πολλὰ δʼ ἄγειρα χρήματα 14.285:—so in Med., ἀγειρόμενοι κατὰ δῆμον 13.14.

data.quote: δημόθεν ἄλφιτα . . καὶ αἴθοπα οἶνον ἀγείρας

children.definition: collect by begging, ὡς ἂν πύρνα κατὰ μνηστῆρας ἀγείροι 17.362, cf. Hdt. 1.61; ἀφʼ ὧν ἀγείρει καὶ προσαιτεῖ D. 8.26:—abs., collect money for the gods, Νύμφαις ἀ. A. Fr. 168, cf. Hdt. 4.35, Pl. R. 381d, SIG 1015.26 ( Halicarnassus); esp. for Cybele, Luc. Alex. 13, cf. μητραγύρτης:—abs., go about begging, Philostr. VA 5.7, Man. 6.299, Max.Tyr. 19.3, etc.

data.quote: ὡς ἂν πύρνα κατὰ μνηστῆρας ἀγείροι

children.definition: put things together, accumulate arguments, as in a speech, A. Ch. 638.
ὀφρύας εἰς ἓν ἀ. frown, AP 5.299 ( Paul.Sil.).—Rare in good Prose.
without cornice, EM 8.55.

definition: ἀγείτης ὑβριστής, Hsch., EM 8.51. (Perh. f.l. for ἀλείτης.)

children.definition: neighbourless, πάγος A. Pr. 272; οἶκος φίλων ἀ. E. El. 1130; ἄφιλος καὶ ἀ. Plu. Def.orac. 2.423e.
to be gregarious, flock, Arist. HA 597b7, 610b2, Nic.Dam. p.151 D.; ἐς τὴν ἤπειρον Men.Prot. p.49 D.:— Act., ἀγελάσαι· κομίσαι, Hsch.
pertaining to cattle-breeding; ἡ ἀγελαιοκομική (sc. τέχνη) the art of breeding and keeping cattle, Pl. Plt. 275esq., 299d.
belonging to a herd, in Hom. always with βοῦς, Il. 11.729, Od. 10.410, al., cf. S. Aj. 175; βοσκήματα E. Ba. 677; αἱ ἀ. τῶν ἵππων, i.e. brood-mares, X. Eq. 5.8.

children.label: II
children.definition: in herds or shoals, gregarious, ἰχθύες Hdt. 2.93; ἀγελαῖα, τά, gregarious animals, Pl. Plt. 264d; opp. μοναδικά, σποραδικά, Arist. HA 487b34, Pol. 1256a23; πολιτικὸν ὁ ἄνθρωπος ζῷον πάσης μελίττης καὶ παντὸς ἀ. ζῴου μᾶλλον ib. 1253a8.

of the common herd, ἀ. ἄνθρωποι, opp. ἄρχοντες, Pl. Plt. 268a; hence, common, ordinary, ἀ. ἰσχάδες Eup. 374; ἄρτοι Pl.Com. 76; κεραμίδες SIG 2587.209, cf. Ath.Mitt. 22.182 (Lebad.):— σοφισταί Isoc. 12.18, νῆσοι Philostr. Im. 2.17; proparox. in this sense, Eust. 1752.63.
keeping of herds, Pl. Plt. 261e.
of or fit for ἀγελαιοτροφία: ἡ -κή, = foreg. [ἀγελαιοτροφία], Pl. Plt. 267b.
keeping herds, Max.Tyr. 26.6, al.
a place for herds ( τὰ ἀγελαῖα), pasture, Suid.
members of an ἀγέλη II, GDI 4952 ( Dreros).
lead a herd or company, Ph. 1.679: c. gen., 1.658, Plu. Galb. 17.

leader of a flock or herd, Procl. in Cra. p.38 P.; ἀ. ταῦρος Luc. Am. 22: generally, leader, captain, Plu. Rom. 6; τῶν φιλοσοφίας ἐραστῶν Procl. in Prm. p.526S.:—also ἀγέλ-αρχος, ὁ, dub. l. in Ph. 2.144.

definition: ἀγελαρχία, ἡ, IGRom. 3.648 ( Idebessus, ii A. D.):— Adj. ἀγελ-αρχικός, prob. l. for -ιανός, ibid.

children.definition: gathering, crowd, νούσων Procl. H. 7.44.
to be ἀγέλαστος, Heraclit. Ep. 7.2, 9.
without laughter, Pl. Euthd. 278e, Thphr. Fr. 124, Plu. QConv. 2.727a.
gregarious, social, Ph. 2.202, Max.Tyr. 21.7.

not laughing, grave, gloomy, h.Cer. 200; ἀ. πρόσωπα βιαζόμενοι A. Ag. 794; of the orator Crassus, Lucil. ap. Cic. Fin. 5.30, cf. Vett.Val. 75.11: metaph., Σίβυλλα ἀγέλαστα φθεγγομένη Heraclit. 92; ἀ. φρήν A. Fr. 290; βίος Phryn.Com. 18; ἀ. πέτρα, stone at Eleusis on which Demeter sat, SIG 2587.183, Apollod. 1.5.1.

children.label: II

Heraclid. Pol. 15.

children.definition: Hsch. (cod. ἀγελάστους), cf. GDI 5142 ( Oaxos).

definition: ἀγελείη, ἡ, Ep. epith. of Athena,

children.definition: driver of spoil, the forager, Il. 6.269, etc., cf. Hes. Sc. 197.

children.label: II
children.definition: ἀγελεία, ἡ, mystical name of Seven, Theol.Ar. 42.30.

herd, of horses, Il. 19.281; elsewhere in Hom. always of oxen and kine, Il. 11.678, etc., cf. βούνομος·—also, any herd or company, συῶν ἀ. Hes. Sc. 168; ἀ. παρθένων Pi. Fr. 112; μαινάδων E. Ba. 1022; πτηνῶν ἀγέλαι S. Aj. 168, E. Ion 106; shoal of fish, Opp. H. 3.639: metaph., πόνων ἀγέλαι E. HF 1276:—also in Pl. R. 451c, Arist. HA 570a27, etc., but rare in early Prose.

definition: ἀγεληΐς, ίδος, ἡ, pecul. fem. of ἀγελαῖος, Numen. ap. Ath. 7.327b.

of the flock, πρόβατα Sammelb. 4322.9 (i A. D.).

unborn, uncreated, Pl. Ti. 27c.

children.label: III

children.label: II

Fr. 860; ἀγένητα ποιεῖν, ἅσσʼ ἂν ᾖ πεπραγμένα Agatho 5; αἰτίαι ἀ. groundless charges, Aeschin. 3.225; διαβολαί Alciphr. 3.58; ὕπνοι ἀ. baseless dreams, Phld. D. 1.22; ὧν οὐδὲν . . ἀ. was left undone, Isoc. 20.8.

Fr. 14; of noble actions, ἀ. ἕργματα Pi. N. 6.34; νίκη O. 10(11).79; πλούτου στεφάνωμʼ ἀ. lordly crown of wealth, P. 1.50; high-spirited, Philostr. Im. 2.2, al.; ἀγέρωχα σκιρτᾶν ib. 32; -ότερα γυμνάσια Id. Gym. 46.

EN 1179b15; τῶν ἀγαθῶν Phld. Ir. p.60 W.; προβλήματα ἀμφιβολίας καὶ ζητήσεως ἄ. Alex.Aphr. Pr. Praef.:—abs., without eating, ἄποτοι καὶ ἄ. Luc. Tim. 18.

Hom., of the aegis, Il. 2.447; κῦδος ἀ. Pi. P. 2.52; χάριν τʼ ἀγήρων ἕξομεν E. Supp. 1178: in Prose, τὸν ἀγήρων ἔπαινον Th. 2.43; ἀθάνατον καὶ ἀ. πάθος Pl. Phlb. 15d, etc.
eternal youth, Sch. Il. 11.1.
pot-marjoram, Origanum Onites, Dsc. 4.58.

stone used by shoemakers to polish womenʼs shoes, Gal. 12.201, Asclep. ap. Aët. 8.43.

Sol. 5.3:—of things, ῥόδων ἀ. ἔρνος Anacreont. 53.36.

LXX Am. 7.13, al.

LXX 4 Ma. 7.9.
without seed or stone, Thphr. CP 5.5.1, Aët. 9.30.

Od. 14.105; ἀ. αἶγας μνηστήρεσσι 22.198; ἀγίνεον ἄσπετον ὕλην Il. 24.784; freq. of offerings, dedications, etc., δῶρα ἀγίνεον Hdt. 3.89, cf. 93, 97, etc., Hp. Ep. 27, Herod. 4.87, Call. Iamb. 1.251, AP 6.75 ( Paul.Sil.); πλοῦτον ἀ. εἰς ἀρετήν Crates Theb. 10.8; ληιάδας ἀ. lead captive, A.R. 1.613; ἄνθεα τοσσάπερ ὧραι ποικίλʼ ἀγινεῦσι Call. Ap. 82; τέτρατον ἦμαρ ἀ., of the moon, Arat. 792; keep, observe, παιγνίην Herod. 3.55:— Med., cause to be brought, ἐς τὸ ἱρὸν ἀγινεόμενος γυναῖκας Hdt. 7.33:— Pass., Arr. Ind. 32.7; αἴκα τὰ πάθεα τᾶς ψυχᾶς ἐς τὸ μέτριον ἀγινῆται Hippod. ap. Stob. 4.1.94.

Mir. 834b11; ἅγιον, τό, temple, OGI 56.59 ( Canopus), LXX Ex. 26.33, al., cf. Ep.Hebr. 9.2; τὸ ἅ. τῶν ἁγίων Holy of Holies, LXX l.c.; τὰ ἅ. τῶν ἁ. 3 Ki. 8.6, etc., cf. Ep.Hebr. 9.3.

ceremony, Call. Aet. 1.1.3 [Fr. 178.3 Pf.].

holiness, sanctity, LXX 2 Ma. 3.12, Ep.Rom. 1.4, etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: PMeyer 24.2 (vi A. D.).

definition: ἀγκ-, Poet. abbrev. for ἀνακ- in compds. of ἀνά.

children.definition: lift up in the arms, νεκρὸν ἀπὸ χθονὸς ἀγκάζοντο Il. 17.722; λίθον ἀγκάσσασθαι Call. Hec. 21.1 [Fr. 236.1 Pf.], cf. Nonn. D. 7.318.
in the arms, ἄ. λαβεῖν τι A. Eu. 80.
resting on the elbows, A. Ag. 3; also expl. as contr. for ἀνέκαθεν, = ἄνωθεν, on the top, cf. Sch. ad l.c., Hsch., AB 337.

bent arm, mostly in pl., ἐν ἀγκάλαις A. Ag. 723, Supp. 481, E. Alc. 351, al.; prov., ἐν ταῖς ἀ. περιΦέρειν τινά X. Cyr. 7.5.50; without ἐν, ἀγκάλαις ἔχειν, περιΦέρειν, E. IT 289, Or. 464; ἐπʼ ἀγκάλαις λαβεῖν Id. Ion 761, cf. IT 1250; ἐς ἀ. Ion 1598; πρὸς ἀγκάλαις πεσεῖν ib. 962; ὑπʼ ἀγκάλαις σταθείς Id. Andr. 747: rarely in sg., Corinn. 19 (s.v.l.); φέρειν ἐν τῇ ἀ. Hdt. 6.61, cf. X. l.c., Timocl. 7.4.
bend of knee, Cael.Aur. TP 5.1.2.

children.label: II
children.definition: anything closely enfolding, κυμάτων ἐν ἀγκάλαις Archil. 23; πετραία ἀ. A. Pr. 1019; πόντιαι ἀ. Id. Ch. 587, cf. E. Or. 1378; πελαγίοις ἐν ἀ. Nausicr. 1.3; of the air, γῆν..ἔχονθʼ ὑγραῖς ἐν ἀ. E. Fr. 941.

children.label: III
children.definition: bundle, sheaf, BGU 1180 (i B. C.), PLond. 1.131r396 (i A. D.), POxy. 935.19 (iii A. D.).
carry a bundle, Paus.Gr. Fr. 90.
carrying an armful or bundle, of beasts of burden; ἀγκαλιδη-φόρος, ἀγκᾰλῐδη-φορέω being used of men, Poll. 2.139, 7.109.
Stud.Pont. 3.6 ( Amisus).
embrace, ὅστις κακὸν ἀγκαλίζεται Semon. 7.77; εἰς τρυΦερὰς ἠγκαλίσασθε χέρας AP 12.122 ( Mel.), cf. Man. 1.45; χεροῖν εἴδωλον ἠγκαλισμένος Lyc. 142: ἀγκαλιζόμενος in pass. sense, Aesop. 366.
Hsch.
arms, Ep. dat. pl. ἀγκαλίδεσσιν Il. 18.555, 22.503; ὑπʼ ἀγκαλίσιν IG 9(1).882.13 ( Corcyra).
armful, Ar. Fr. 418, Nicostr. 24, Ister 54 (s. v. l.), Ph. 5.147C., Plu. Rom. 8.

children.label: II
children.definition: J. AJ 5.1.2, Hsch.
that which is embraced or taken in the arms, Luc. Am. 14: hence, darling, Lyc. 308.

children.label: II
children.definition: embrace, metaph., ἀ. κλυσιδρομάδος αὔρας Tim. Pers. 91.
making into bundles, POxy. 1631.9 (iii A.D.).
armful, bundle, h.Merc. 82.

definition: ἀγκαλπίς κρημνός, οἱ δὲ βόθρον, Hsch.

children.definition: into or in the arms, ἔχε δʼ ἀ. ἄκοιτιν Il. 14.353, cf. Theoc. 8.55, A.R. 1.276; ἀ. ἔμαρπτε Il. 14.346; ἀ. ἐλάζετο θνγατέρα ἥν 5.371; τρόπιν ἀ. ἑλὼν νεός Od. 7.252; ἀ. δʼ ἀλλήλων λαβέτην (of wrestlers) Il. 23.711.
Hsch.; metapl. dat. pl. ἀγκάσιν Opp. H. 2.315.

definition: ἀγκηθής ἀβλαβής, Hsch. ἀγκής· ἀντηχής, Hsch.

children.definition: angling, Pl. Lg. 823d.
of or for angling: τὸ -κόν, angling, Pl. Sph. 220d; -κὴ τέχνη Gal. Thras. 30.

definition: ἀγκίστριον, τό, Dim. of ἄγκιστρον, Theoc. 21.57, Bito 51.1.

children.definition: with a hook bound to it, δόναξ AP 6.27 ( Theaet.).
hook-shaped, barbed, Placit. 1.3.18, etc. Adv. -δῶς Erot. s.v. ἠγκίστρενται.
fish-hook, Od. 4.369, Hdt. 2.70, etc.; hook of a spindle, Pl. R. 616c; surgical instrument, Philum. Ven. 2.6, Cael.Aur. TP 5.1; generally, hook, D.C. 60.35.
fasten with hooks, ῥαφαῖς ὑπὸ τὰς ἐπιπτυχὰς τὴν συμπλοκὴν ἀγκιστρώσαντες Hld. 9.15.2.

data.quote: ῥαφαῖς ὑπὸ τὰς ἐπιπτυχὰς τὴν συμπλοκὴν ἀγκιστρώσαντες

children.definition: grip, πόθῳ .. ἠγκιστρωμένη Lyc. 67.

children.label: II
children.definition: fit with hooks or barbs, Plu. Crass. 25.
seller of fish-hooks, Poll. 7.198.
biting the hook, Arist. HA 621b1.
barbed, βέλος Plb. 6.23.10; ἐμβόλια Ph. Bel. 95.45.
Dor. for ἀνακλήριον, reapportionment, CIG 2562.13 ( Hierapytna).

definition: ἀγκλίνω, and ἄγκλιμα, τό, poet. for ἀνακλ-.

children.definition: ἀγκάλη, only in pl., Ζηνὸς . . ἐν ἀγκοίνῃσιν ἰανεις Il. 14.213, cf. Od. 11.261, Hes. Fr. 245, A.R. 2.954.2. metaph., anything enfolding, ἐν χθονὸς ἀγκοίναις AP 9.398 ( Jul.Aegypt.), cf. Opp. H. 3.34.

children.label: II
children.definition: halyard, IG 2.794b20, al., prob. in Alc. 18.9.
Poll. 3.155. ἀγκόλαι· ἀγκῶνες, Hsch.
Ar. Lys. 1311, as if from ἀνακονίω, = ἐγκονέω.
bend, hollow: hence, mountain glen, Il. 20.490, Od. 4.337, Hes. Op. 389, Hdt. 6.74, Theoc. 8.33, etc.; Trag. only E. Ba. 1051. (Cf. Skt. áñcati ‘bend’, Lat. ancus, uncus, etc.)

definition: ἀγκοτύλη, ἡ, a game, Hsch. ἀγκταλιάζει· ἄγχει, Hsch. ἄγκτειρα, ἡ, fem. of sq., ποιναί Orac.Chald. 265.

children.definition: instrument for closing wounds, Cels. 5.26, Plu. Tranq. 2.468c, Heliod. ap. Orib. 44.10.4, Gal. 1.385.
Poll. 2.134, Hsch.
bonds, Procl. in Euc. 20.25F.: metaph., τῆς ὕλης Id. in R. 2.150 K., prob. in Alc. p.41c.
bandage, Heliod. ap. Orib. 48.28.5.
bind with an ἀγκτήρ (instrument for closing wounds), Crito ap. Gal. 13.878.
bound with thongs, [ Ἄρης] ἀ., i.e. javelin, Tim. Pers. 23.
hurl like a javelin, Ἔρως κεραυνὸν ἠγκυλημένος Satyr. 1.

bend of the arm or wrist, ἀπ ἀγκύλης ἱέναι, a phrase descriptive of the way in which the cottabus was thrown, B. Fr. 13.2, cf. Hsch.; ἀπ ἀγκύλης ζησι λάταγας Cratin. 273; wrongly expl. as cup, Ath. 11.782d.
bend of the knee, ham, Philostr. Im. 2.6, Sch. Il. 23.726.
joint bent and stiffened by disease, Hp. Liqu. 6, cf. Poll. 4.196.

children.label: II
children.definition: loop, noose, πλεκτὰς ἀγκύλας E. IT 1408; in the leash of a hound, X. Cyn. 6.1; in bandages, Gal. 18(1).790; in torsion-engines, Hero Bel. 83.1.
thong of a javelin, by which it was hurled, Str. 4.4.3; hence, the javelin itself, E. Or. 1476, cf. Plu. Phil. 6; διʼ ἀγκυλῶν ἱππόται Them. Or. 21.256d.
bow-string, ἀ. χρυσόστροΦοι S. OT 203.
ἀγκύλη τῆς ἐμβάδος sandal- thong, Alex. 31.
curtain-ring, hook, LXX Ex. 38.18 ( 36.34), al.; hook for a door, IG ΙΙ(2).165.11, al. ( Delos, iii B.C.).
sides of the κεραία, Poll. 1.91.
Adj. of ἀγκυλέομαι, thrown from the bent arm, of the cottabus, A. Fr. 179.

children.label: II
children.definition: Subst., ἀγκυλητόν, τό, javelin, Id. Fr. 16, IG 2.733 B17.
having a loop for a handle ( ἀγκύλη II), Hp. ap. Gal. 19.69.
clasp the adversaryʼs neck, dub. l. in Poll. 1.176.
Dim. of ἀγκύλη, loop in noose, Heracl. ap. Orib. 48.2.1; link of a chain, AB 329, Suid.
Antyll. ap. Orib. 45.15.1.

children.label: II
children.definition: τὰ ἀγκύλια, = Lat. ancilia, Plu. Num. 13.
hook, barb, Opp. C. 1.155.
bend back, Aret. SA 1.6, cf. Hsch.
adhesion of the eyelids, Cels. 7.7.
contraction of the tongue, Orib. 45.15 tit., Paul.Aeg. 6.29; and ἀγκῠλό-γλωσσος, ὁ, one who suffers from it, Aët. 8.38.

definition: ἀγκυλογλώχιν, ῑνος, ὁ, of a cock,

children.definition: with hooked spurs, Babr. 17.3.
crook-necked, Opp. H. 4.630.
crook-toothed, of a scimitar, Q.S. 6.218; ἀ. χαλινοί, of anchors, Nonn. D. 3.50.

children.label: II
children.definition: barbed, AP 6.176 ( Maced.).
winding, τόποι, Suid. s.v. ἄγκη.
hamstring, dub. in PLond. 2.415.15.
curved in spires, of a dragonʼs tail, Nonn. D. 35.217.
crook-limbed, Κᾶρες Archestr. Fr. 41B.
contest with javelin, IPE 12.435 ( Chersonesus).

definition: ἀγκυλομήτης ( Boeot. ἀγκουλομείτας Corinn. Supp. 1.13), ὁ, (μῆτις)

children.definition: crooked of counsel, epith. of Κρόνος. Il. 2.205, Od. 21.415, al., Hes. Th. 18, etc.; of Prometheus, ib. 546, Op. 48.

data.ref: Hes. Th. 18, etc.; of Prometheus, ib.

definition: ἀγκυλόμητις, ιος, ὁ, ἡ, = foreg., Nonn. D. 21.255.
ἀγκυλόπους, ὁ, ἡ, πουν, τό, gen. ποδος,

children.definition: with bent legs, δίφρος, = Lat. sella curulis, Plu. Mar. 5.

crooked, curved, τόξα Il. 5.209, Od. 21.264, etc.; ἅρμα Il. 6.39; κάλαμος Theoc. 21.47; of the eagle, ἀγκύλον κάρα beaked, Pi. P. 1.8; ἀ. ἐκ τῶν ὀδόντων Ant.Lib. 22.6; of greedy fingers, hooked, Ar. Eq. 205; of the movement of a snake, ἀ. ἕρπων D.P. 123.

data.ref: Ar. Eq. 205; of the movement of a snake,

children.definition: intricate, Luc. Bis Acc. 21; ἐριστικὸς καὶ ἀ. τὴν γλῶσσαν catchy, Alciphr. 3.64; in good sense, terse, D.H. Th. 25 ( Comp.). Adv. -λως ib. 31; intricately, Procl. in Prm. p.525 S., Dam. Pr. 187.
wily, crafty, Lyc. 344; -ώτεραι ἐνέδραι Archig. ap. Orib. 8.2.24.
with crooked bow, Παίονες Il. 2.848, 10.428; Μήδειοι Pi. P. 1.78.
with hooked beak, αἰετός Od. 19.538, AP 6.229 ( Crin.); αἰγυπιοί Il. 16.428, Hes. Sc. 405, Batr. 294. (Perh. -χήλης shd. always be read.)
with crooked claws, v.l. in Batr. 294, Ar. Eq. 197, cf. Sch. ( χείλης codd.).
crook, bend, τὴν χεῖρα, as in throwing the cottabus, Pl.Com. 47:— Pass., ὄνυχας ἠγκυλωμένος with crooked claws, Ar. Av. 1180.
tongue-tie, Antyll. ap. Orib. 46.16.4; stiffening of joints, Paul.Aeg. 4.55; adhesion of the eyelids, Gal. 14.772.
furnished with a thong, στοχάσματα E. Ba. 1205.

anchor, Alc. 18.9 (v. ἄγκοινα), Thgn. 459; ἄ. βάλλεσθαι, καθιέναι, μεθιέναι, ἀφιέναι to cast anchor, Pi. I. 6(5).13, Hdt. 7.36, A. Ch. 662, X. An. 3.5.10; ἄ. αἴρειν, αἴρεσθαι to weigh anchor, Plu. Pomp. 50, 80; ἀνέλοιο AP 10.1 ( Leon.); τὰς νέας ἔχειν ἐπʼ ἀγκυρέων Hdt. 6.12; ὁρμίζειν Th. 7.59; ἐπʼ ἀγκυρέων ὁρμεῖν ride at anchor, Hdt. 7.188; νηῦς μιῆς ἐπ ἀγκύρης [οὐκ ἀσφ]αλὴς ὁρμεῦσα Herod. 1.41; ἐπ ἀγκύρας ἀποσαλεύειν D. 50.22, cf. E. Hel. 1071; prov., ἀγαθαὶ πέλοντʼ . . δύʼ ἄγκυραι ʼtis good to have ‘two strings to your bow’, Pi. O. 6.101; ἐπὶ δυοῖν ἀγκύραιν ὁρμεῖν αὐτοὺς ἐᾶτε D. 56.44, cf. Plu. Sol. 19; ἄ. δʼ ἥ μου τὰς τύχας ὤχει μόνη E. Hel. 277; ἐπὶ τῆς αὐτῆς (sc. ἀγκύρας) ὁρμεῖν τοῖς πολλοῖς, i.e. ‘to be in the same boat’ with the many, D. 18.281; εἰσὶ μητρὶ παῖδες ἄγκυραι βίου S. Fr. 685; οἴκων ἄ., of a son, E. Hec. 80; ἱερὰ ἄ., last hope, Luc. JTr. 51.

data.quote: νηῦς μιῆς ἐπ ἀγκύρης [οὐκ ἀσφ]αλὴς ὁρμεῦσα
ἐπὶ δυοῖν ἀγκύραιν ὁρμεῖν αὐτοὺς ἐᾶτε
ἄ. δʼ ἥ μου τὰς τύχας ὤχει μόνη

Democr. 148.

definition: ἀγκυρίζω, fut. Att. ῐῶ, (ἄγκυρα) in wrestling,

children.definition: hook with the leg, trip, διαλαβὼν ἀγκυρίσας Ar. Eq. 262; ἀγκυρίσας ἔρρηξεν Eup. 262.

definition: ἀγκύριον, τό, Dim. of ἄγκῡρα, Ph. Bel. 100.34, Plu. Exil. 2.604d, Arr. Epict. fr. 30, Demoph. Sim. 45, Luc. Cat. 1.

children.label: II
children.definition: ἀγκύρια (sc. πείσματα), τά, anchor-cables, D.S. 14.73.
hook, in wrestling, Schol. Ar. Eq. 262, Hsch.
anchor-stone, Hsch. s.v. μασχάλην.
secure by throwing an anchor: hook fast in, fasten securely, ἠγκυροβόληται Hp. Dent. 18.
anchorage, Str. 3.4.7 (pl.), Plu. Garr. 2.507b.
anchor-shaped, Dsc. 3.158, Gal. 2.766. Adv. -ειδῶς Erot. s.v. ῥυβδοειδέα τρόπον.

definition: ἀγκυρόμαχος, ὁ, a kind of ship, Isid. Etym. 19.1.16, Gloss.

a holding by the anchor, ἐν ἀγκυρουχίαις A. Supp. 766.
bent like an anchor, δοκίδες Ph. Bel. 85.36.

bend of the arm, hence, elbow, ὀρθωθεὶς δʼ ἐπʼ ἀγκῶνος Il. 10.80; ἦ, καὶ ἐπʼ ἀγκῶνος κεΦαλὴν σχέθεν Od. 14.494; ἀγκῶνα τυχὼν μέσον Il. 5.582, cf. 20.479; ἀγκῶνι νύττειν to nudge, Od. 14.485, cf. Pl. Amat. 132b; κροτεῖν τοῖς ἀγκῶσιν τὰς πλευράς D. 54.9; prov., ἀγκῶνι ἀπομύττεσθαι Bion ap. D.L. 4.46; ἐπʼ ἀγκῶνος δειπνεῖν, of the attitude at meals, Luc. Lex. 6.

data.quote: ἦ, καὶ ἐπʼ ἀγκῶνος κεΦαλὴν σχέθεν

children.definition: arm, Νίκας ἐν ἀγκώνεσσι πίτνειν Pi. N. 5.42; ἐς δʼ ὑγρὸν ἀγκῶνα . . προσπτύσσεται S. Ant. 1237, etc.
bend in animals’ legs, X. Cyn. 4.1.

children.label: II
children.definition: any nook or bend, as the angle of a wall, ἀγκὼν τείχεος Il. 16.702, cf. Hdt. 1.180; bend, bay of a river, Id. 2.99; ἕσπεροι ἀγκῶνες S. Aj. 805; headlands which form a bay, Str. 12.8.19; ἀγκῶνες κιθάρας ribs which support the horns of the cithara, Semus I, Hsch.; ends of stomach-bow, Hero Bel. 78.4; arms of torsion-engine, Ph. Bel. 53.40, al., Hero Bel. 81.9; cross-bar of same, Bito 49.12; arm of throne or chair, LXX 2 Ch. 9.18, Cael.Aur. TP 2.1; perh. clamp, PPetr. 3p.144.
vase, Artem. 1.74, cf. Sammelb. 4292.

children.label: III
children.definition: γλυκὺς ἀ. used κατʼ ἀντίφρασιν of a difficulty, Pl. Phdr. 257d, Clearch. 6; expl. by Sch. Pl. l.c., Zen. 2.92, Ath. 12.516a, from a long bend or reach in the Nile; but apptly. = παραγκάλισμα, thing to be embraced, treasure, Pl.Com. 178; also = ἀβρότονον, Dsc. 3.24. (For the Root v. ἄγκος.)
recline at table, Gloss.

children.label: II
children.definition: Med., pursue a sinuous course, hence metaph., use circumlocutions, Com.Adesp. 14.8D.
elbow, Gal. 4.452.

definition: ἀγκωνίσκιον, τό, Dim. of ἀγκών, Hero Spir. 1.42.
ἀγκωνίσκος, ὁ, = foreg., Hero Spir. 1.42, LXX Ex. 26.17.

children.definition: a bending, reach, of an estuary, Eust. 1712.29.
cubital, Gloss.
curve-shaped, curved, Bito 58.9 (v.l.),
bright-haired, h.Pan. 5.

splendour, beauty, κῦδός τε καὶ ἀ. καὶ ὄνειαρ Od. 15.78; ἀγλαΐηφι πεποιθώς Il. 6.510; of Penelope, Od. 18.180; splendour, magnificence, S. El. 211; ὡρῶν Jul. Or. 4.148d; in bad sense, pomp, show, [ κύνας] ἀγλαΐης ἕνεκεν κομέουσιν Od. 17.310; in pl., vanities, 17.244, E. El. 175.

data.quote: κῦδός τε καὶ ἀ. καὶ ὄνειαρ

children.definition: joy, triumph, Pi. O. 13.14, etc.; pl., festivities, merriment, Hes. Sc. 272, 285.
adornment, of a horseʼs mane, colours of oysterʼs shell, etc., X. Eq. 5.8, Ael. NA 10.13, cf. A.R. 4.1191.
Ἀγλαΐα, one of the Graces, who presided over victory in the games, Hes. Th. 945, cf. B. 3.6.

senses.definition: Hp. Mul. 2.188, Ael., v. infr.: fut. Att. ἀγλαϊῶ ( ἐπ-) Ar. Ec. 575: aor. ἠγλάϊσα ( Dor. ἀγλ-) Theoc. Ep. 1.4, etc., ( ἐπ-) Ar. Fr. 682:— Pass., v. infr.:— make splendid, glorify, B. 3.22, etc.; ἀθανάταις ἠγλάϊσεν χάρισιν IG 12(3).1190.10 ( Melos); θυσίαις τέμενος Isyll. 28, cf. Plu. Sollert. 2.965c, Ael. NA 8.28.

children.definition: give as an honour, σοί, Βάκχε, τάνδε μοῦσαν ἀγλαΐζομεν Carm.Pop. 8, cf. Theoc. l.c.

children.label: II
children.definition: Ep. and Lyr. only Med. and Pass., adorn oneself with a thing, take delight in, σέ φημι διαμπερὲς ἀγλαϊεῖσθαι (sc. ἵπποις) Il. 10.331 (the only form in Hom., even of compds.); ὅστις τοιούτοις θυμὸν ἀγλαΐζεται Semon. 7.70; ἀ. μουσικᾶς ἐν ἀώτῳ Pi. O. 1.14; Com., ἐλαίῳ ῥάφανος ἠγλαϊσμένη Ephipp. 3.6 (cf. Eub. 150).

children.label: III
children.definition: ἀγλαΐζει· θάλλει, Hsch., cf. Antiph. 301 codd.—Never in Trag. or Att. Prose.

ornament, honour, A. Ag. 1312; of a child, μητρὸς ἀ. E. Hel. 11, cf. 282; of the hair of Orestes placed on his fatherʼs tomb, A. Ch. 193, S. El. 908, cf. E. El. 325; of a sarcophagus, IG 12(8).600 ( Thasos).— Poet. and late Prose; ἀ. φυτῶν, of the rose, Ach.Tat. 2.1.

data.ref: 282; of the hair of Orestes placed on his fatherʼs tomb,

children.definition: adorning, ornament, ῥημάτων Pl. Ax. 369d.
adorned, Hsch.
with splendid bunches, Nonn. D. 18.4.
beautiful-limbed, Ἥβα Pi. N. 7.4.
with beautiful trees, Pi. O. 9.20.
bestowing splendid gifts, Δημήτηρ h.Cer. 54, 192, 492.
ennobled by works, Max. 68.
with splendid throne, bright-throned, Μοῖσαι Pi. O. 13.96, cf. N. 10.1, B. 16.124.
noble-hearted, AP 15.40.25 ( Cometas).

bearing beautiful or goodly fruit, of fruit-trees, ῥοιαί Od. 7.115, 11.589; Σικελία Pi. Fr. 106; εἰρήνη Epigr. ap. SIG 274 ( Delph., iv B. C.): of Demeter and the Nymphs, givers of the fruits of the earth, h.Cer. 4, 23.

rich in fair youths, Κόρινθος Pi. O. 13.5.
giving splendour to the feast, φωνή Pi. O. 3.6.
brightly smiling, Ἔρως Eurytus ( PLG 3.639).
of rare wisdom, Tryph. 183, Procl. H. 5.10.

of beauteous form, AP 9.524, Orph. H. 14.5, al.
rich in fair children, Opp. H. 2.41, Epigr.Gr. 896 ( Syria).
beautifully veiled, Q.S. 11.240.
with beautiful arms, Nonn. D. 32.80.
